   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    Ferdinand Marcos
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div class="noprint" id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
    </div>

      navigation
     </a>

     </a>

        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div style="width:52px">
          <img alt="Unbalanced scales.svg" data-file-height="354" data-file-width="400" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Unbalanced_scales.svg/45px-Unbalanced_scales.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Unbalanced_scales.svg/68px-Unbalanced_scales.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Unbalanced_scales.svg/90px-Unbalanced_scales.svg.png 2x" width="45"/>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          The
          <b>
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Neutral_point_of_view" title="Wikipedia:Neutral point of view">
            neutrality
           </a>
           of this article is
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NPOV_dispute" title="Wikipedia:NPOV dispute">
            disputed
           </a>
          </b>
          .
          <span class="hide-when-compact">
           Relevant discussion may be found on the
           <a href="/wiki/Talk:Ferdinand_Marcos#Excess_in_the_lede_section,_possibly_abuse" title="Talk:Ferdinand Marcos">
            talk page
           </a>
           . Please do not remove this message until
           <a href="/wiki/Template:POV#When_to_remove" title="Template:POV">
            conditions to do so are met
           </a>
           .
          </span>
          <small>
           <i>
            (January 2018)
           </i>
          </small>
          <small class="hide-when-compact">
           <i>
            (
            <a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">
             Learn how and when to remove this template message
            </a>
            )
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       This article is about a former President of the Philippines. For his son, a politician and former senator of the Philippines, see
       <a href="/wiki/Bongbong_Marcos" title="Bongbong Marcos">
        Ferdinand Marcos Jr.
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       In this
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_name" title="Philippine name">
        Philippine name
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_name" title="Middle name">
        middle name
       </a>
       or maternal
       <a href="/wiki/Surname" title="Surname">
        family name
       </a>
       is
       <i>
        Edralin
       </i>
       and the surname or paternal family name is
       <i>
        Marcos
       </i>
       .
      </div>

         </span>
         September 11, 1917
         <br/>
         <a href="/wiki/Sarrat" title="Sarrat">
          Sarrat
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Ilocos_Norte" title="Ilocos Norte">
          Ilocos Norte
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Insular_Government_of_the_Philippine_Islands" title="Insular Government of the Philippine Islands">
          Philippine Islands
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row">
         Died
        </th>
        <td>
         <span class="nowrap">
          September 28, 1989
          <span style="display:none">
           (
           <span class="dday deathdate">
            1989-09-28
           </span>
           )
          </span>
          (aged 72)
         </span>
         <br/>
         <a href="/wiki/Honolulu" title="Honolulu">
          Honolulu
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">
          Hawaii
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
          U.S.
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row">
         Resting place
        </th>
        <td class="label">

          Ferdinand E. Marcos Presidential Center
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Batac" title="Batac">

         </a>
         , Ilocos Norte
         <br/>

         </small>
         <br/>

         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Taguig" title="Taguig">

         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">

         </a>
         <br/>
         <small>
          (since November 18, 2016)
         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>

              <br/>
              about
             </span>

       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;text-align:center;">
         <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
          <ul>
           <li class="nv-view">
            <a href="/wiki/Template:Ferdinand_E._Marcos_series" title="Template:Ferdinand E. Marcos series">
             <abbr title="View this template">
              v
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-talk">
            <a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Ferdinand_E._Marcos_series" title="Template talk:Ferdinand E. Marcos series">
             <abbr title="Discuss this template">
              t
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-edit">
            <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Ferdinand_E._Marcos_series&amp;action=edit">

              e
             </abbr>
            </a>

        </td>

      </table>
      <p>
       <b>
        Ferdinand Emmanuel Edralin Marcos Sr.
       </b>
       (September 11, 1917 – September 28, 1989) was a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Filipino_people" title="Filipino people">
        Filipino
       </a>
       politician and
       <a href="/wiki/Kleptocracy" title="Kleptocracy">
        kleptocrat
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economistHailToTheThief_2-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-economistHailToTheThief-2">
         [1]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PoliticalWill_3-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-PoliticalWill-3">
         [2]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wintrobe_4-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-wintrobe-4">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RegimeOfMarcoses_5-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-RegimeOfMarcoses-5">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The10BQuestion_6-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-The10BQuestion-6">
         [5]
        </a>
       </sup>
       who was
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Philippines" title="President of the Philippines">
        President of the Philippines
       </a>
       from 1965 to 1986. He ruled as a
       <a href="/wiki/Dictator" title="Dictator">
        dictator
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dictatorMarcosHeroesBurial_7-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-dictatorMarcosHeroesBurial-7">
         [6]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosRiseAndFallDictator_8-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosRiseAndFallDictator-8">
         [7]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-conjugal_9-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-conjugal-9">
         [8]
        </a>
       </sup>
       under
       <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_No._1081" title="Proclamation No. 1081">
        martial law
       </a>
       from 1972 until 1981.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lacsamana1990p189_10-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-lacsamana1990p189-10">
         [9]
        </a>
       </sup>
       His regime was infamous for its corruption,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-corruptionInThePhilippinesMarcosWorst_11-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-corruptionInThePhilippinesMarcosWorst-11">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transparency.org_12-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-transparency.org-12">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global_Corruption_Report_13-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Global_Corruption_Report-13">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
        <a href="#cite_note-14">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       extravagance,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fpImmenseIllGottenWealthOfImelda_15-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-fpImmenseIllGottenWealthOfImelda-15">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theIndependentWeirdWorldImelda_16-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-theIndependentWeirdWorldImelda-16">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jimLaurieABCExcerpt_17-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-jimLaurieABCExcerpt-17">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and brutality.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosFamilyReturnLimelight_18-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosFamilyReturnLimelight-18">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-amnestyInternational1975_19-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-amnestyInternational1975-19">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hartfordMcCoy_20-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-hartfordMcCoy-20">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Marcos claimed an active part in
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       , including fighting alongside the Americans in the
       <a href="/wiki/Bataan_Death_March" title="Bataan Death March">
        Bataan Death March
       </a>
       and being the "most decorated war hero in the Philippines".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMedalsExplained_21-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosMedalsExplained-21">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A number of his claims were found to be false
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wapoNewDoubtsMarcosWarRole_22-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-wapoNewDoubtsMarcosWarRole-22">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
        <a href="#cite_note-23">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fakeMedalsReduxI_24-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-fakeMedalsReduxI-24">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fakeMedalsReduxII_25-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-fakeMedalsReduxII-25">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosHeroism_26-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosHeroism-26">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army" title="United States Army">
        United States Army
       </a>
       documents described Marcos's wartime claims as "fraudulent" and "absurd".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcoswartime_27-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcoswartime-27">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Marcos started as an attorney, then served in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_House_of_Representatives" title="Philippine House of Representatives">
        Philippine House of Representatives
       </a>
       from 1949 to 1959 and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_Senate" title="Philippine Senate">
        Philippine Senate
       </a>
       from 1959 to 1965. He was elected President in 1965, and presided over a growing economy during the beginning and intermediate portion of his 20-year rule,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
        <a href="#cite_note-28">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but ended in loss of livelihood, extreme poverty, and a crushing debt crisis.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-goldenAgeLookAtData_29-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-goldenAgeLookAtData-29">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-truthAboutEconomy_30-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-truthAboutEconomy-30">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-openSpyAgency_31-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-openSpyAgency-31">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Marcos placed the Philippines under martial law on September 23, 1972,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nightDeclared_32-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nightDeclared-32">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govPhDeclarationMartialLaw_33-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-govPhDeclarationMartialLaw-33">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fmDeclaresSundayExpress_34-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-fmDeclaresSundayExpress-34">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       during which he revamped the constitution, silenced the media,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ageSilence_35-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ageSilence-35">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and used violence and oppression
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hartfordMcCoy_20-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-hartfordMcCoy-20">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       against the political opposition,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kushidaStanford_36-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-kushidaStanford-36">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Muslims, communist rebels,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_37-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-auto-37">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and ordinary citizens.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whatMartialLawWasLike_38-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-whatMartialLawWasLike-38">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Martial law was ratified by 90.77% of the voters during the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Martial_Law_referendum,_1973" title="Philippine Martial Law referendum, 1973">
        Philippine Martial Law referendum, 1973
       </a>
       though the referendum was marred with controversy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-philippinesReadr_39-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-philippinesReadr-39">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-politicalEconomyOfAuthoritarianism_40-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-politicalEconomyOfAuthoritarianism-40">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Public outrage led to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Snap_elections_of_1986" title="Snap elections of 1986">
        snap elections of 1986
       </a>
       . Allegations of mass cheating, political turmoil, and
       <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Marcos#Human_rights_abuses" title="Ferdinand Marcos">
        excesses of human rights abuses
       </a>
       led to the
       <a href="/wiki/People_Power_Revolution" title="People Power Revolution">
        People Power Revolution
       </a>
       in February 1986, which removed him from power.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-countryStudiesAquinoAssassination_41-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-countryStudiesAquinoAssassination-41">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       To avoid what could have been a military confrontation in Manila between pro- and anti-Marcos troops, Marcos was advised by President
       <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">
        Ronald Reagan
       </a>
       through Sen.
       <a href="/wiki/Paul_Laxalt" title="Paul Laxalt">
        Paul Laxalt
       </a>
       to "cut and cut cleanly",
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WPostCutcleanly_42-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-WPostCutcleanly-42">
         [41]
        </a>
       </sup>
       after which Marcos fled to Hawaii.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosFlees_43-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosFlees-43">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Marcos was succeeded by
       <a href="/wiki/Corazon_Aquino" title="Corazon Aquino">
        Corazon "Cory" Aquino
       </a>
       , widow of the assassinated opposition leader
       <a href="/wiki/Benigno_Aquino_Jr." title="Benigno Aquino Jr.">
        Senator Benigno "Ninoy" Aquino Jr.
       </a>
       who had flown back to the Philippines to
       <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Benigno_Aquino_Jr." title="Assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr.">
        face Marcos
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-countryStudiesAquinoAssassination_41-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-countryStudiesAquinoAssassination-41">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-undeliveredSpeech_44-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-undeliveredSpeech-44">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-laurieAssassionation_45-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-laurieAssassionation-45">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aquinoFinalJourney_46-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-aquinoFinalJourney-46">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to source documents provided by the
       <a href="/wiki/Presidential_Commission_on_Good_Government" title="Presidential Commission on Good Government">
        Presidential Commission on Good Government
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-huffMissingMarcosBillions_47-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-huffMissingMarcosBillions-47">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29Mrecovered_48-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-29Mrecovered-48">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1billion30_49-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-1billion30-49">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the Marcos family had stolen US$5–10 billion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-asianJournalChronology_50-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-asianJournalChronology-50">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The PCGG also maintained that the Marcos family enjoyed a decadent lifestyle—taking away billions of dollars
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-huffMissingMarcosBillions_47-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-huffMissingMarcosBillions-47">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1billion30_49-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-1billion30-49">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       from the country
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-broughtToHawaii_51-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-broughtToHawaii-51">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-politicalWill_52-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-politicalWill-52">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
       between 1965 and 1986. His wife
       <a href="/wiki/Imelda_Marcos" title="Imelda Marcos">
        Imelda Marcos
       </a>
       , whose excesses during the couple's
       <a href="/wiki/Conjugal_dictatorship" title="Conjugal dictatorship">
        conjugal dictatorship
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-regimeMarcosesCroniesKleptocracy_53-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-regimeMarcosesCroniesKleptocracy-53">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosToGaddafi_54-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosToGaddafi-54">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imeldificPaintings_55-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-imeldificPaintings-55">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       made her infamous in her own right, spawned the term "Imeldific".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosFamilyReturnLimelight_18-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosFamilyReturnLimelight-18">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-martialLawFashion_56-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-martialLawFashion-56">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imeldificDinner_57-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-imeldificDinner-57">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imeldificAt82_58-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-imeldificAt82-58">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Two of their children,
       <a href="/wiki/Imee_Marcos" title="Imee Marcos">
        Imee Marcos
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Bongbong_Marcos" title="Bongbong Marcos">
        Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr.
       </a>
       are still active in Philippine politics.
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>

        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-56">

          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           Reparations
          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-57">
         <a href="#Legacy">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           11
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           Legacy
          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-58">
         <a href="#See_also">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           12
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           See also
          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-59">
         <a href="#Notes">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           13
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           Notes
          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-60">
         <a href="#References">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           14
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           References
          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-61">
           <a href="#Sources">

             14.1
            </span>

            </span>
           </a>
          </li>

        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-62">

          </span>

          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-63">

          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">
        Early life
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       Ferdinand Edralin Marcos was born on September 11, 1917, in the town of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sarrat,_Ilocos_Norte" title="Sarrat, Ilocos Norte">
        Sarrat, Ilocos Norte
       </a>
       , to
       <a href="/wiki/Mariano_Marcos" title="Mariano Marcos">
        Mariano Marcos
       </a>
       and Josefa Edralin (1893—1988).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Steinberg2000pp115-116_59-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Steinberg2000pp115-116-59">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He was later baptized into the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Independent_Church" title="Philippine Independent Church">
        Philippine Independent Church
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
        <a href="#cite_note-60">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but was first baptized in the Roman Catholic Church at the age of three.
      </p>
      <p>
       In December 1938, Ferdinand Marcos was prosecuted for the murder of
       <a href="/wiki/Julio_Nalundasan" title="Julio Nalundasan">
        Julio Nalundasan
       </a>
       . He was not the only accused from the Marcos clan; also accused was his father, Mariano, his brother, Pio, and his brother-in-law Quirino Lizardo. Nalundasan, one of the elder Marcos's political rivals, had been shot and killed in his house in
       <a href="/wiki/Batac" title="Batac">
        Batac
       </a>
       on September 21, 1935 – the day after he had defeated Mariano Marcos a second time for a seat in the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_the_Philippines" title="National Assembly of the Philippines">
        National Assembly
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mijares237_61-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mijares237-61">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to two witnesses, the four had conspired to assassinate Nalundasan, with Ferdinand Marcos eventually pulling the trigger. In late January 1939, they were finally denied bail
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
        <a href="#cite_note-62">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and later in the year, they were convicted. Ferdinand and Lizardo received the
       <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_the_Philippines" title="Capital punishment in the Philippines">
        death penalty
       </a>
       for premeditated murder, while Mariano and Pio were found guilty of
       <a href="/wiki/Contempt_of_court" title="Contempt of court">
        contempt of court
       </a>
       . The Marcos family took their appeal to the
       <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_Philippines" title="Supreme Court of the Philippines">
        Supreme Court of the Philippines
       </a>
       , which overturned the lower court's decision on 22 October 1940, acquitting them of all charges except contempt.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
        <a href="#cite_note-63">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Marcos studied law at the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Philippines" title="University of the Philippines">
        University of the Philippines
       </a>
       , attending the prestigious
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Philippines_College_of_Law" title="University of the Philippines College of Law">
        College of Law
       </a>
       . He excelled in both curricular and extra-curricular activities, becoming a valuable member of the university's swimming, boxing, and wrestling teams. He was also an accomplished and prolific
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oration" title="Oration">
        orator
       </a>
       , debater, and writer for the student newspaper. He also became a member of the University of the Philippines
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ROTC" title="ROTC">
        ROTC
       </a>
       Unit (UP Vanguard Fraternity) where he met some of his future cabinet members and
       <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Philippines" title="Armed Forces of the Philippines">
        Armed Forces
       </a>
       Chiefs of Staff. When he sat for the 1939 Bar Examinations, he received
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2016)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       a near-perfect score of 98.8%, although some have disputed this score. The Philippine Supreme Court felt justified in altering his scoring.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2016)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       He graduated
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cum_laude" title="Cum laude">
         cum laude
        </a>
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2016)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2016)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       He was elected to the
       <a href="/wiki/Pi_Gamma_Mu" title="Pi Gamma Mu">
        Pi Gamma Mu
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Phi_Kappa_Phi" title="Phi Kappa Phi">
        Phi Kappa Phi
       </a>
       international
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Honour_society" title="Honour society">
        honor societies
       </a>
       , the latter giving him its Most Distinguished Member Award 37 years later.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
        <a href="#cite_note-64">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In Seagrave's book
       <i>
        The Marcos Dynasty
       </i>
       , he mentioned that Marcos possessed a
       <a href="/wiki/Eidetic_memory" title="Eidetic memory">
        phenomenal memory
       </a>
       and exhibited this by memorizing complicated texts and reciting them forward and backward, even such as the 1935 Constitution of the Philippines. Sen. Miriam Defensor-Santiago, in an interview with the
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_Star" title="Philippine Star">
         Philippine Star
        </a>
       </i>
       on March 25, 2012, shared her experience as a speech writer to President Marcos: "One time, the Secretary of Justice forgot to tell me that the President had requested him to draft a speech that the President was going to deliver before graduates of the law school. And then, on the day the President was to deliver the speech, he suddenly remembered because Malacañang was asking for the speech, so he said, 'This is an emergency. You just have to produce something.' And I just dictated the speech. He liked long speeches. I think that was 20 or 25 pages. And then, in the evening, I was there, of course. President Marcos recited the speech from memory."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
        <a href="#cite_note-65">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">
        Personal life
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Personal life">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       He was married to
       <a href="/wiki/Imelda_Marcos" title="Imelda Marcos">
        Imelda Romualdez
       </a>
       , on May 1, 1954 and the marriage produced three children:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govph_66-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-govph-66">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ol>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Imee_Marcos" title="Imee Marcos">
         Maria Imelda "Imee" Marcos
        </a>
        (born 12 November 1955), Governor of Ilocos Norte
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Marcos_Jr." title="Ferdinand Marcos Jr.">
         Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr.
        </a>
        (born 13 September 1957), Senator of the Philippines
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irene_Marcos-Araneta" title="Irene Marcos-Araneta">
         Irene Marcos
        </a>
        (born 16 September 1960)
       </li>
      </ol>
      <p>
       His fourth child, Aimee Romualdez Marcos, was adopted and was a musician in 2012
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
        <a href="#cite_note-67">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Ancestry">
        Ancestry
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Ancestry">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Marcos claimed that he was a descendant of
       <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Luna" title="Antonio Luna">
        Antonio Luna
       </a>
       , a Filipino general during the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War" title="Philippine–American War">
        Philippine–American War
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A.R._Ocampo_2010_68-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-A.R._Ocampo_2010-68">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He also claimed that his ancestor was a 16th-century pirate
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lim_Hong_(pirate)" title="Lim Hong (pirate)">
        Lim-A-Hong
       </a>
       (Chinese: 林阿鳳) who used to raid the coasts of the
       <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">
        South China Sea
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
        <a href="#cite_note-69">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mijares255_70-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mijares255-70">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table class="collapsible collapsed" style="margin: 0.3em auto auto; clear:none; min-width:100%; width:100%; font-size:88%; border:1px solid #aaa;">
       <tr>
        <th style="padding:0.2em 0.3em 0.2em 4.3em;background:none; width:100%">
         Ancestors of Ferdinand Marcos
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
          <a href="#cite_note-71">
           [70]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </th>
       </tr>

            </td>
            <td colspan="4" rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid black;padding:0 0.2em;padding-top: 0; padding-bottom: 0;;background-color: #ffc;">
             4. Fabián Marcos
            </td>
            <td colspan="6" rowspan="2">

              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">
              </span>
             </div>
            </td>

           <tr style="text-align: center;">
            <td>
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">
              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">
              </span>
             </div>
            </td>
            <td colspan="4" rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid black;padding:0 0.2em;padding-top: 0; padding-bottom: 0;;background-color: #bfc;">
             14. ? Gustillo/Quetulio
            </td>
            <td colspan="3" rowspan="2">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">
              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">
              </span>
             </div>
            </td>
           </tr>
           <tr style="text-align: center;">
            <td style="border-left: 1px solid black; border-top: 1px solid black;">

           </tr>
           <tr style="text-align: center;">
            <td rowspan="6" style="border-left: 1px solid black;">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">
              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">
              </span>
             </div>
            </td>
            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">
              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">
              </span>
             </div>
            </td>
            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">

             </div>
            </td>
            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">
              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">
              </span>
             </div>
            </td>
            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">

              </span>
             </div>
            </td>
            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">

            </td>

              </span>
             </div>
            </td>

           </tr>

            <td colspan="6" rowspan="2">

            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">

             </div>
            </td>
            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">

              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">

           </tr>

             </div>
            </td>
            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">
              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">
              </span>
             </div>
            </td>
            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">
              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">
              </span>
             </div>
            </td>
            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">
              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">
              </span>
             </div>
            </td>
            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">
              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">
              </span>
             </div>
            </td>
            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">
              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">
              </span>
             </div>
            </td>
            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">
              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">
              </span>
             </div>
            </td>
            <td rowspan="6">
             <div style="width: 0.5em; height: 0.5em;">
              <span style="font: 1px/1px serif;">
              </span>
             </div>
            </td>
           </tr>
           <tr style="text-align: center;">
            <td>
            </td>
           </tr>
           <tr style="text-align: center;">
            <td>
            </td>
           </tr>
           <tr style="text-align: center;">
            <td>
            </td>
           </tr>
           <tr style="text-align: center;">
            <td>
            </td>
           </tr>
           <tr style="text-align: center;">
            <td>
            </td>
           </tr>
          </table>
         </center>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Military_career">
        Military career
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Military career">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       The subject of Marcos's military career has been the subject of debate and controversy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcoswartime_27-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcoswartime-27">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyTimesMarcosWartime_73-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nyTimesMarcosWartime-73">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Before World War II, Marcos was already a Reserve Officers' Training Corps graduate during his time studying law.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheWashPost_74-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TheWashPost-74">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hours after the
       <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">
        attack on Pearl Harbor
       </a>
       on December 8, 1941, the Japanese simultaneously bombed many places in the Philippines, including Clark Field. The 14th Army began its invasion with a landing on Batan Island (not to be confused with Bataan Peninsula), 120 miles (190 km) off the north coast of Luzon on the same day, by selected naval infantry units. Landings on Camiguin Island and at Vigan, Aparri, and Gonzaga in northern Luzon followed two days later.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-agoncillo404_75-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-agoncillo404-75">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Marcos was one of those who were called into the army as a 3rd lieutenant during the mobilization in the summer and fall of 1941. The U.S. Army has confirmed that Ferdinand Marcos fought on the U.S. side after the December 1941 Japanese invasion of the Philippines until April 1942, before being taken prisoner.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheWashPost_74-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-TheWashPost-74">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He also had records showing that he fought on the American side again from December 1944 until the end of the war.
      </p>
      <p>
       Marcos would be one of the 78,000 Filipino and American troops who surrendered at Bataan on April 9, 1942, four months after the Japanese initiated their
       <a href="/wiki/Philippines_Campaign_(1941%E2%80%9342)" title="Philippines Campaign (1941–42)">
        invasion of the Philippines
       </a>
       . He survived the
       <a href="/wiki/Bataan_Death_March" title="Bataan Death March">
        Bataan Death March
       </a>
       that followed the surrender.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mijares246_76-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mijares246-76">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1962, Marcos would claim to be the "most decorated war hero of the Philippines" by garnering almost every medal and decoration that the Filipino and American governments could give to a soldier.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mijares246_76-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-mijares246-76">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Included in his 27 war medals and decorations are that of the
       <a href="/wiki/Distinguished_Service_Cross_(United_States)" title="Distinguished Service Cross (United States)">
        Distinguished Service Cross
       </a>
       (allegedly pinned by General
       <a href="/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur" title="Douglas MacArthur">
        Douglas MacArthur
       </a>
       ) and the
       <a href="/wiki/Medal_of_Honor" title="Medal of Honor">
        Medal of Honor
       </a>
       (allegedly pinned by General
       <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_M._Wainwright_(general)" title="Jonathan M. Wainwright (general)">
        Jonathan M. Wainwright
       </a>
       ); these claims have been discredited.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcoswartime_27-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcoswartime-27">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Marcos was not listed in General Douglas MacArthur's "List of Recipients of Awards and Decorations" issued from December 7, 1941 through June 30, 1945 that was compiled in Tokyo, and General Jonathan Wainwright's list of 120 Americans and Filipinos who were awarded during the Bataan campaign by the War Department shortly before his surrender.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AJ_77-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-AJ-77">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheWashPost2_78-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TheWashPost2-78">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colonel Manriquez and Adjutant Captain Rivera who were the commanders of the 14th Infantry, whom Marcos claimed to have served under, attested that Marcos was not a soldier, but was a non-combatant and a Civil Affairs officer. Marcos did receive campaign ribbons given to all combatant and non-combatant participants "in the defense of Bataan and in the resistance."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PhilStar1_79-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-PhilStar1-79">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Later research showed the wartime exploits of Marcos to be mostly propaganda, being inaccurate or untrue.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
        <a href="#cite_note-81">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
        <a href="#cite_note-82">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
        <a href="#cite_note-83">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
        <a href="#cite_note-85">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1986, research by historian
       <a href="/wiki/Alfred_W._McCoy" title="Alfred W. McCoy">
        Alfred W. McCoy
       </a>
       into United States Army records showed most of Marcos's medals to be fraudulent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyTimesMarcosWartime_73-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-nyTimesMarcosWartime-73">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AlfredMcCoy_86-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-AlfredMcCoy-86">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to Ricardo José, former chairman of the Department of History of the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Philippines" title="University of the Philippines">
        University of the Philippines
       </a>
       , Marcos's claims in his self-commissioned autobiography
       <i>
        Marcos of the Philippines
       </i>
       that Gen.
       <a href="/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur" title="Douglas MacArthur">
        Douglas MacArthur
       </a>
       pinned on him the
       <a href="/wiki/Distinguished_Service_Cross_(United_States)" title="Distinguished Service Cross (United States)">
        Distinguished Service Cross
       </a>
       medal for delaying Japanese at
       <a href="/wiki/Bataan" title="Bataan">
        Bataan
       </a>
       for 3 months was highly improbable.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-roblesMarcosMedals_87-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-roblesMarcosMedals-87">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As with many stories about members of the Marcos family, there is some controversy about the exact nature of the death of
       <a href="/wiki/Mariano_Marcos" title="Mariano Marcos">
        Mariano Marcos
       </a>
       , whom numerous schools were named after. Some versions saying he was executed by the Japanese in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bacnotan,_La_Union" title="Bacnotan, La Union">
        Bacnotan, La Union
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
        <a href="#cite_note-88">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
        <a href="#cite_note-89">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and others saying that he was a collaborator and was killed by guerrillas related to Julio Nalundasan, the man Ferdinand Marcos had been accused of killing before the war.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LaphamsRaiders_90-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LaphamsRaiders-90">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
        <a href="#cite_note-91">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       John Sharkey of the
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Washington_Post" title="Washington Post">
         Washington Post
        </a>
       </i>
       found records that Marcos was in the list of those that were released due to either "having severe health problems and those whose families have cooperated with the Japanese military authorities."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheWashPost2_78-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-TheWashPost2-78">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since Marcos's name did not appear in the 1942
       <i>
        Manila Tribune
       </i>
       list of ailing prisoners that were released by the Japanese, Sharkey believed that Marcos may have been freed due to his connections with his father.
      </p>
      <p>
       Marcos also claimed to have led a 9,000-man guerrilla force called
       <i>
        Ang
        <a href="/wiki/Maharlika" title="Maharlika">
         Mahárlika
        </a>
       </i>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_language" title="Tagalog language">
        Tagalog
       </a>
       , "The Freeman")
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whScottPrehispanic_92-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-whScottPrehispanic-92">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in northern
       <a href="/wiki/Luzon" title="Luzon">
        Luzon
       </a>
       during
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       . His account of events was later cast into doubt after a United States military investigation exposed many of his claims as either false or inaccurate.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
        <a href="#cite_note-93">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Meanwhile, Marcos claimed that he was able to get the United States
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Adjutant_General" title="Adjutant General">
        Adjutant General
       </a>
       to recognize 3,500 individual claims of soldiers then under his command.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mijares261_94-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mijares261-94">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Despite criticisms on Marcos's claims, according to the 1992 presidential inaugural biography of President
       <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Ramos" title="Fidel Ramos">
        Fidel Ramos
       </a>
       who turned his back on Ferdinand Marcos during the People Power Revolution, his father
       <a href="/wiki/Narciso_Ramos" title="Narciso Ramos">
        Narciso Ramos
       </a>
       served as one of the leaders of the guerrilla group Maharlika founded by President Ferdinand Marcos.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
        <a href="#cite_note-95">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Congressional_career">
        Congressional career
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Congressional career">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="House_of_Representatives">
        House of Representatives
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: House of Representatives">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       When the Philippines was granted independence on July 4, 1946 by the American government, the Philippine Congress was established. Marcos ran and was three times elected as representative of the 2nd district of Ilocos Norte, 1949–1959. He was named chairman of the House Committee on Commerce and Industry and member of the Defense Committee headed by Ramon Magsaysay. He was chairman, House Neophytes Bloc in which (President) Diosdado Macapagal, (Vice President) Emmanuel Pelaez and (Manila Mayor) Arsenio J. Lacson were members. He was also a member of the House Committee on Industry; LP spokesman on economic matters; member, Special Committee on Import and Price Controls and on Reparations; House Committees on Ways and Means, Banks Currency, War Veterans, Civil Service, Corporations and Economic Planning; and the House Electoral Tribunal.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ferdinand_Edralin_Marcos_96-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ferdinand_Edralin_Marcos-96">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Senate">
        Senate
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Senate">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       After he served as member of the House of Representatives for three terms, Marcos won his senate seat in the elections in 1959 and became the Senate minority floor leader in 1960. He became the executive vice president of the Liberal Party in and served as the party president from 1961 to 1964.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Senate_Presidency">
        Senate Presidency
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Senate Presidency">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       From 1963 to 1965, he became the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Senate_President_of_the_Philippines" title="Senate President of the Philippines">
        Senate President
       </a>
       . Thus far, he is the last Senate President to become President of the Philippines. He introduced a number of significant bills, many of which found their way into the Republic statute books.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ferdinand_Edralin_Marcos_96-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ferdinand_Edralin_Marcos-96">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Presidency">
        Presidency
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Presidency">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ferdinand_Marcos_at_the_White_House.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="990" data-file-width="712" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Ferdinand_Marcos_at_the_White_House.jpg/170px-Ferdinand_Marcos_at_the_White_House.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Ferdinand_Marcos_at_the_White_House.jpg/255px-Ferdinand_Marcos_at_the_White_House.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Ferdinand_Marcos_at_the_White_House.jpg/340px-Ferdinand_Marcos_at_the_White_House.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ferdinand_Marcos_at_the_White_House.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Marcos at the
         <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">
          White House
         </a>
         in 1966.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em">

         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>

        </td>

      <h3>
       <span id="First_term_.281966.E2.80.931969.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="First_term_(1966–1969)">
        First term (1966–1969)
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: First term (1966–1969)">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="infobox" style="width:22em;width:26em; padding: 0px;">
       <caption>
        <small>

        </th>
       </tr>

      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Presidential_campaign">
        Presidential campaign
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Presidential campaign">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_presidential_election,_1965" title="Philippine presidential election, 1965">
        Philippine presidential election, 1965
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Marcos ran a populist campaign emphasizing that he was a bemedalled war hero emerging from
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       . In 1962, Marcos would claim to be the
       <i>
        most decorated war hero of the Philippines
       </i>
       by garnering almost every medal and decoration that the Filipino and American governments could give to a soldier.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mijares246_76-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-mijares246-76">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Included in his claim of 27 war medals and decorations are that of the
       <a href="/wiki/Distinguished_Service_Cross_(United_States)" title="Distinguished Service Cross (United States)">
        Distinguished Service Cross
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Medal_of_Honor" title="Medal of Honor">
        Medal of Honor
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mijares246_76-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-mijares246-76">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chicagoTribune1_98-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-chicagoTribune1-98">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to Primitivo Mijares, author of the book
       <a href="/wiki/Conjugal_dictatorship" title="Conjugal dictatorship">
        Conjugal dictatorship
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
        <a href="#cite_note-99">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the opposition Liberal Party would later confirm that many of his war medals were only acquired in 1962 to aid in his reelection campaign for the Senate, not for his presidential campaign.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mijaresphoto_100-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mijaresphoto-100">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Marcos won the presidency in 1965.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Vietnam_War">
        Vietnam War
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Vietnam War">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       To the surprise of many, soon after becoming president, Marcos wanted the Philippines to become involved, although in a limited way, in the
       <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">
        Vietnam War
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-agoncillo508_102-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-agoncillo508-102">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He asked Congress to approve sending a
       <a href="/wiki/Combat_engineer" title="Combat engineer">
        combat engineer
       </a>
       unit to South Vietnam. When the previous Philippine president, Macapagal, suggested sending troops in 1964–1965, it was Marcos who led the opposition to this plan on both legal and moral grounds. Despite opposition to the new plan, the Marcos government gained Congressional approval and Philippine troops were sent from the middle of 1966 as the Philippines Civic Action Group (PHILCAG). PHILCAG reached a strength of some 1,600 troops in 1968 and between 1966 and 1970 over 10,000 Filipino soldiers served in South Vietnam, mainly being involved in civilian infrastructure projects.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
        <a href="#cite_note-103">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources">
          <span title="The material near this tag may rely on an unreliable source. (June 2011)">
           unreliable source?
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Second_term_.281969.E2.80.931972.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Second_term_(1969–1972)">
        Second term (1969–1972)
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Second term (1969–1972)">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ferdinand_Marcos_second_inauguration.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1888" data-file-width="2585" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Ferdinand_Marcos_second_inauguration.jpg/250px-Ferdinand_Marcos_second_inauguration.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Ferdinand_Marcos_second_inauguration.jpg/375px-Ferdinand_Marcos_second_inauguration.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Ferdinand_Marcos_second_inauguration.jpg/500px-Ferdinand_Marcos_second_inauguration.jpg 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ferdinand_Marcos_second_inauguration.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Ferdinand Marcos takes the Oath of Office for a second term before
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_Philippines" title="Chief Justice of the Philippines">
          Chief Justice
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Roberto_Concepcion" title="Roberto Concepcion">
          Roberto Concepcion
         </a>
         on December 30, 1969
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="1969_Presidential_Election">
        1969 Presidential Election
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: 1969 Presidential Election">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_presidential_election,_1969" title="Philippine presidential election, 1969">
        Philippine presidential election, 1969
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1969, Marcos was reelected for a second term—the first and the last Filipino president to win a second full term.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
        <a href="#cite_note-104">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
        <a href="#cite_note-105">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
        <a href="#cite_note-106">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
        <a href="#cite_note-107">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       His running mate, incumbent Vice President
       <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Lopez" title="Fernando Lopez">
        Fernando Lopez
       </a>
       was also elected to a third full term as
       <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_Philippines" title="Vice President of the Philippines">
        Vice President of the Philippines
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="First_Quarter_Storm_and_rumored_coup_d.27.C3.A9tat_and_plot_to_assassinate_President_Marcos">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="First_Quarter_Storm_and_rumored_coup_d'état_and_plot_to_assassinate_President_Marcos">
        First Quarter Storm and rumored coup d'état and plot to assassinate President Marcos
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: First Quarter Storm and rumored coup d'état and plot to assassinate President Marcos">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/First_Quarter_Storm" title="First Quarter Storm">
        First Quarter Storm
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Around 1970, student activism was raging and many student activists joined the ranks of the communists.
       <a href="/wiki/Kabataang_Makabayan" title="Kabataang Makabayan">
        Kabataang Makabayan
       </a>
       (Patriotic Youth, or 'KM') a political organization founded by
       <a href="/wiki/Jose_Maria_Sison" title="Jose Maria Sison">
        Jose Maria Sison
       </a>
       intended to be a nationwide extension of the Student Cultural Association of the University of the Philippines,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:8_108-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-:8-108">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
        <a href="#cite_note-109">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
       carried out study sessions on Marxism–Leninism and intensified the deployment of urban activists in rural areas to prepare for
       <a href="/wiki/People%27s_war" title="People's war">
        People's war
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ndfp.org_110-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ndfp.org-110">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The line between leftist activists and communists became increasingly blurred, as a significant number of KM advanced activists joined the party of the Communist Party also founded by
       <a href="/wiki/Jose_Maria_Sison" title="Jose Maria Sison">
        Jose Maria Sison
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ndfp.org_110-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ndfp.org-110">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Earlier, during the campaign period for the 1969 elections, students called promoted a mock campaign called the
       <i>
        Dante-for-President
       </i>
       movement, likely referring to
       <a href="/wiki/New_People%27s_Army" title="New People's Army">
        New People's Army
       </a>
       founder
       <a href="/wiki/Bernabe_Buscayno" title="Bernabe Buscayno">
        Bernabe 'Kumander Dante' Buscayno
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lacaba_1982_11–45,_157–178_112-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Lacaba_1982_11–45,_157–178-112">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       KM members protested in front of Congress, throwing a coffin, a stuffed alligator, and stones at Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos after his State of the Nation Address. On the presidential palace, activists rammed the gate with a fire truck and once the gate broke and gave way, the activists charged into the Palace grounds tossing rocks, pillboxes, Molotov cocktails. In front of the US embassy, protesters vandalized, arsoned and damaged the embassy lobby resulting to a strong protest from the U.S. Ambassador.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ndfp.org_110-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-ndfp.org-110">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lacaba_1982_11–45,_157–178_112-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Lacaba_1982_11–45,_157–178-112">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-philippinediaryproject.wordpress.com_113-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-philippinediaryproject.wordpress.com-113">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The KM protests ranged from 50,000 to 100,000 in number per weekly mass action.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ndfp.org_110-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-ndfp.org-110">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the aftermath of the January 1970 riots, at least two activists were confirmed dead and several were injured by the police. The mayor of Manila at the time,
       <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Villegas" title="Antonio Villegas">
        Antonio Villegas
       </a>
       , commended the
       <a href="/wiki/Manila_Police_District" title="Manila Police District">
        Manila Police District
       </a>
       for their "exemplary behavior and courage" and protecting the First Couple long after they have left. The death of the activists was seized by the Lopez controlled Manila Times and Manila Chronicle, blaming Marcos and added fire to the weekly protests.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_114-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-114">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Students declared a week-long boycott of classes and instead met to organize protest rallies.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lacaba_1982_11–45,_157–178_112-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Lacaba_1982_11–45,_157–178-112">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In Marcos's diary,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-philippinediaryproject.wordpress.com_113-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-philippinediaryproject.wordpress.com-113">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_114-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-114">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       he wrote that the whole crisis has been utilized by communism to create a revolutionary situation. He lamented that the powerful Lopez family, which controlled Manila Times and Manila Chronicle, blamed him for the riots thus raising the ire of demonstrators. He mentioned that he was informed by his mother of a planned assassination paid for by the powerful oligarch, Eugenio Lopez Sr (Iñing Lopez). He narrated how he dissuaded his supporters from the Northern Philippines in infiltrating the demonstration in Manila and inflicting harm on the protesters, and how he showed to the UP professors that the Collegian was carrying the communist party articles and that he was disappointed in the faculty of his
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Alma_mater" title="Alma mater">
         alma mater
        </a>
       </i>
       for becoming a spawning ground of communism. He also added that he asked Ernesto Rufino, Vicente Rufino and Carlos Palanca to withdraw advertisements from the Manila Times which was openly supporting revolution and the communist cause, and they agreed to do so.
      </p>
      <p>
       Rumors of coup d'état were also brewing. A report of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee said that shortly after the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_presidential_election,_1969" title="Philippine presidential election, 1969">
        Philippine presidential election, 1969
       </a>
       , a group composed mostly of retired colonels and generals organized a revolutionary junta with the aim of first discrediting President Marcos and then killing him. The group was headed by Eleuterio Adevoso, an official of the opposition Liberal party. As described in a document given to the committee by Philippine Government official, key figures in the plot were Vice President Fernando Lopez and Sergio Osmena Jr., whom Marcos defeated in the 1969 election.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
        <a href="#cite_note-115">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Marcos even went to the U.S. embassy to dispel rumors that the U.S. embassy is supporting a coup d'état which the opposition liberal party was spreading.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_114-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-114">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       While the report obtained by the NY Times speculated saying that story could be used by Marcos to justify Martial Law, as early as December 1969 in a message from the U.S. Ambassador to the U.S. Assistant Secretary of State, the U.S. Ambassador said that most of the talk about revolution and even assassination has been coming from the defeated opposition, of which Adevoso (of the Liberal Party) is a leading activist. He also said that the information he has on the assassination plans are 'hard' or well-sourced and he has to make sure that it reached President Marcos.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
        <a href="#cite_note-116">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In light of the crisis, Marcos wrote an entry in his diary in January 1970:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_114-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-114">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       "I have several options. One of them is to abort the subversive plan now by the sudden arrest of the plotters. But this would not be accepted by the people. Nor could we get the Huks (Communists), their legal cadres and support. Nor the MIM (Maoist International Movement) and other subversive [or front] organizations, nor those underground. We could allow the situation to develop naturally then after massive terrorism, wanton killings and an attempt at my assassination and a coup d'etat, then declare martial law or suspend the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus – and arrest all including the legal cadres. Right now I am inclined towards the latter."
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Martial_Law_and_the_New_Society_.281972.E2.80.931981.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Martial_Law_and_the_New_Society_(1972–1981)">
        Martial Law and the New Society (1972–1981)
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Martial Law and the New Society (1972–1981)">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="infobox" style="width:22em;width:26em; padding: 0px;">
       <caption>
        <small>
         Economy of the Philippines under
        </small>
        <br/>
        President Ferdinand Marcos
        <br/>
        <small>
         1972–1981
        </small>
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background: lightblue;">
         Population
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal;">
         <b>
          1981
         </b>
        </th>
        <td>
         <span class="mwe-math-element">
          <span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
           <math alttext="{\displaystyle \approx }" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
            <semantics>
             <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">

               <mo>
                ≈
                <!-- ≈ -->
               </mo>
              </mstyle>
             </mrow>
             <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
              {\displaystyle \approx }
             </annotation>
            </semantics>
           </math>
          </span>
          <img alt="\approx " aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6f58f4c2b73283ce8a5ad28fb3746f2a8c998789" style="vertical-align: 0.125ex; margin-bottom: -0.297ex; width:1.808ex; height:1.509ex;"/>
         </span>
         49.5 million
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background: lightblue;">
         Gross Domestic Product
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal;">
         <b>
          1972
         </b>
        </th>
        <td>
         <img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/>
