         </a>
         400,850 million (US$62.24 billion)
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal;">
         <b>
          1981
         </b>
        </th>
        <td>
         <img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/>
         ₱1,782,350 million (US$225.61 billion)
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal;">
         <b>
          Growth rate, 1972–81 average
         </b>
        </th>
        <td>
         5.7%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background: lightblue;">
         Per capita income
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal;">
         <b>
          1972
         </b>
        </th>
        <td>
         <img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/>
         ₱11,000
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal;">
         <b>
          1981
         </b>
        </th>
        <td>
         <img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/>
         ₱37,500
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background: lightblue;">
         <a href="/wiki/Exchange_rate" title="Exchange rate">
          Exchange rates
         </a>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         USD1 = ₱7.90
         <br/>
         ₱1 = USD0.12
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         <i>
          Sources
         </i>
         :
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govph_66-2">
          <a href="#cite_note-govph-66">
           [65]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malacanang.gov.ph_97-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-malacanang.gov.ph-97">
           [96]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wb_118-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-wb-118">
           [117]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Martial_law_in_the_Philippines" title="Martial law in the Philippines">
        Martial law in the Philippines
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       At the height of the armed communist insurgency in the Philippines,
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Military_Academy" title="Philippine Military Academy">
        Philippine Military Academy
       </a>
       instructor Lt Victor Corpuz led
       <a href="/wiki/New_People%27s_Army" title="New People's Army">
        New People's Army
       </a>
       rebels in a raid on the PMA armory, capturing rifles, machine guns, grenade launchers, a bazooka and thousands of rounds of ammunition in 1970.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1972, China, which was then actively supporting and arming communist insurgencies in Asia as part of
       <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">
        Mao Zedong
       </a>
       's
       <a href="/wiki/People%27s_war#List_of_People's_Wars" title="People's war">
        People's War Doctrine
       </a>
       , transported 1,200 M-14 and AK-47 rifles
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
        <a href="#cite_note-120">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
       for the NPA to speed up NPA's campaign to defeat the government.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
        <a href="#cite_note-121">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
        <a href="#cite_note-122">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to interviews by
       <a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">
        The Washington Post
       </a>
       with unnamed former
       <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Philippines" title="Communist Party of the Philippines">
        Communist Party of the Philippines
       </a>
       Officials "the (Communist) party leadership planned – and three operatives carried out – the (Plaza Miranda) attack in an attempt to provoke government repression and push the country to the brink of revolution... (Communist Party Leader) Sison had calculated that Marcos could be provoked into cracking down on his opponents, thereby driving thousands of political activists into the underground, the anonymous former officials said. Recruits were urgently needed, they said, to make use of a large influx of weapons and financial aid that China had already agreed to provide."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-washingtonpost.com_123-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-washingtonpost.com-123">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
       José María Sison continues to deny these claims,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
        <a href="#cite_note-124">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the CPP has never released any official confirmation of their culpability in the incident. Marcos and his allies claimed that Benigno Aquino was part of the plot, which is generally regarded as absurd given that Aquino was pro-American and pro-capitalist.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
        <a href="#cite_note-125">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
        <a href="#cite_note-126">
         [125]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Most historians continue to hold Marcos responsible for the
       <a href="/wiki/Plaza_Miranda_bombing" title="Plaza Miranda bombing">
        Plaza Miranda bombing
       </a>
       as he is known to have used
       <a href="/wiki/False_flag" title="False flag">
        false flag
       </a>
       operations as a pretext for martial law.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
        <a href="#cite_note-127">
         [126]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
        <a href="#cite_note-128">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There were a series of deadly bombings in 1971, and the CIA privately stated that Marcos was responsible for at least one of them. The agency was also almost certain that none of the bombings were perpetrated by Communists. US intelligence documents declassified in the 1990s contained further evidence implicating Marcos, provided by a CIA mole within the Philippine army. Another false flag attack took place with the attempted assassination of Defense Minister
       <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ponce_Enrile" title="Juan Ponce Enrile">
        Juan Ponce Enrile
       </a>
       in 1972.
       <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">
        President Nixon
       </a>
       approved Marcos' martial law initiative immediately afterwards.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
        <a href="#cite_note-129">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ferdinand_Marcos_and_George_Shultz_DA-SC-84-05877.JPEG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1910" data-file-width="2860" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Ferdinand_Marcos_and_George_Shultz_DA-SC-84-05877.JPEG/220px-Ferdinand_Marcos_and_George_Shultz_DA-SC-84-05877.JPEG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Ferdinand_Marcos_and_George_Shultz_DA-SC-84-05877.JPEG/330px-Ferdinand_Marcos_and_George_Shultz_DA-SC-84-05877.JPEG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Ferdinand_Marcos_and_George_Shultz_DA-SC-84-05877.JPEG/440px-Ferdinand_Marcos_and_George_Shultz_DA-SC-84-05877.JPEG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ferdinand_Marcos_and_George_Shultz_DA-SC-84-05877.JPEG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Ferdinand Marcos with U.S. Secretary of State
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/George_Shultz" title="George Shultz">
          George Shultz
         </a>
         , 1982.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>
        It is easier perhaps and more comfortable to look back to the solace of a familiar and mediocre past. But the times are too grave and the stakes too high for us to permit the customary concessions to traditional democratic processes.
       </p>
       <div class="templatequotecite">
        —
        <cite>
         Ferdinand Marcos, January 1973
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
          <a href="#cite_note-130">
           [129]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </cite>
       </div>
      </blockquote>
      <p>
       Marcos declared
       <a href="/wiki/Martial_law" title="Martial law">
        martial law
       </a>
       on September 21, 1972 when his Press Secretary,
       <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Tatad" title="Francisco Tatad">
        Francisco Tatad
       </a>
       , announced on Radio
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nightDeclared_32-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-nightDeclared-32">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govPhDeclarationMartialLaw_33-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-govPhDeclarationMartialLaw-33">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fmDeclaresSundayExpress_34-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-fmDeclaresSundayExpress-34">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       that
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proclamation_%E2%84%96_1081" title="Proclamation № 1081">
        Proclamation № 1081
       </a>
       . which Marcos had signed 2 days earlier on September 21, 1972, had come into force and would extend Marcos's rule beyond the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Philippines" title="Constitution of the Philippines">
        constitutional
       </a>
       two-term limit.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
        <a href="#cite_note-131">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ruling by decree, he almost dissolved
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">
        press freedom
       </a>
       and other
       <a href="/wiki/Civil_liberties" title="Civil liberties">
        civil liberties
       </a>
       to add propaganda machine, closed down Congress and media establishments, and ordered the arrest of opposition leaders and militant activists, including senators
       <a href="/wiki/Benigno_Aquino_Jr." title="Benigno Aquino Jr.">
        Benigno Aquino Jr.
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jovito_Salonga" title="Jovito Salonga">
        Jovito Salonga
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Jose_Diokno" title="Jose Diokno">
        Jose Diokno
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
        <a href="#cite_note-132">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uslc-28_133-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-uslc-28-133">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, unlike Ninoy Aquino's senator colleagues who were detained without charges, Ninoy, together with communist NPA leaders Lt Corpuz and
       <a href="/wiki/Bernabe_Buscayno" title="Bernabe Buscayno">
        Bernabe Buscayno
       </a>
       , was charged with murder, illegal possession of firearms and subversion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-asianjournalusa.com_134-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-asianjournalusa.com-134">
         [133]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Marcos claimed that martial law was the prelude to creating his
       <i>
        Bagong Lipunan
       </i>
       , a "New Society" based on new social and political values.
      </p>
      <p>
       Martial Law was put on vote in July 1973 in the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Martial_Law_referendum,_1973" title="Philippine Martial Law referendum, 1973">
        Philippine Martial Law referendum, 1973
       </a>
       and was marred with controversy
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-philippinesReadr_39-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-philippinesReadr-39">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-politicalEconomyOfAuthoritarianism_40-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-politicalEconomyOfAuthoritarianism-40">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
       resulting to 90.77% voting yes and 9.23% voting no.
      </p>
      <p>
       A
       <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_convention_(political_meeting)" title="Constitutional convention (political meeting)">
        constitutional convention
       </a>
       , which had been called for in 1970 to replace the Commonwealth era
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1935_Constitution_of_the_Philippines" title="1935 Constitution of the Philippines">
        1935 Constitution
       </a>
       , continued the work of framing a new constitution after the declaration of martial law. The new constitution went into effect in early 1973, changing the form of government from presidential to
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">
        parliamentary
       </a>
       and allowing Marcos to stay in power beyond 1973. The constitution was approved by 95% of the voters in the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_constitutional_plebiscite,_1973" title="Philippine constitutional plebiscite, 1973">
        Philippine constitutional plebiscite
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       After putting in force amendments to the constitution, legislative action, and securing his sweeping powers and with the Batasan, his supposed successor body to the Congress, under his control, President Marcos lifted martial law on January 17, 1981. However, the suspension of the privilege of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Writ_of_habeas_corpus" title="Writ of habeas corpus">
        writ of habeas corpus
       </a>
       continued in the autonomous regions of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Mindanao" title="Western Mindanao">
        Western Mindanao
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Mindanao" title="Central Mindanao">
        Central Mindanao
       </a>
       . The opposition dubbed the lifting of martial law as a mere "face lifting" as a precondition to the visit of
       <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">
        Pope John Paul II
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
        <a href="#cite_note-135">
         [134]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Marcos had a vision of a
       <i>
        Bagong Lipunan
       </i>
       (New Society) similar to
       <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">
        Indonesian
       </a>
       president
       <a href="/wiki/Suharto" title="Suharto">
        Suharto
       </a>
       's "
       <a href="/wiki/New_Order_(Indonesia)" title="New Order (Indonesia)">
        New Order administration
       </a>
       ", China leader Mao Zedong's Great Leap Forward and Korean
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kim_Il-Sung" title="Kim Il-Sung">
        Kim Il-Sung
       </a>
       's
       <a href="/wiki/Juche" title="Juche">
        Juche
       </a>
       . He used the years of martial law to implement this vision. According to Marcos's book
       <i>
        Notes on the New Society
       </i>
       , it was a movement urging the poor and the privileged to work as one for the common goals of society and to achieve the liberation of the Filipino people through self-realization.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Philippines" title="University of the Philippines">
        University of the Philippines
       </a>
       economics professor and former
       <a href="/wiki/National_Economic_and_Development_Authority" title="National Economic and Development Authority">
        NEDA
       </a>
       Director-General Dr. Gerardo Sicat,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
        <a href="#cite_note-136">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
       an
       <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology" title="Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
        MIT
       </a>
       Ph.D. graduate, portrayed some of Martial Law's effects as follows:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
        <a href="#cite_note-137">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>
        Economic reforms suddenly became possible under martial law. The powerful opponents of reform were silenced and the organized opposition was also quilted. In the past, it took enormous wrangling and preliminary stage-managing of political forces before a piece of economic reform legislation could even pass through Congress. Now it was possible to have the needed changes undertaken through presidential decree. Marcos wanted to deliver major changes in an economic policy that the government had tried to propose earlier.
       </p>
       <p>
        The enormous shift in the mood of the nation showed from within the government after martial law was imposed. The testimonies of officials of private chambers of commerce and of private businessmen dictated enormous support for what was happening. At least, the objectives of the development were now being achieved...
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
         <a href="#cite_note-138">
          [137]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </p>
      </blockquote>
      <p>
       During his martial law regime, Marcos confiscated and appropriated by force and duress many businesses and institutions, both private and public, and redistributed them to his cronies and close personal friends. Two of these friends were
       <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Cojuangco_Jr." title="Eduardo Cojuangco Jr.">
        Eduardo "Danding" Cojuangco Jr.
       </a>
       , who would go on to control
       <a href="/wiki/San_Miguel_Corporation" title="San Miguel Corporation">
        San Miguel Corporation
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Ramon_Cojuangco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Ramon Cojuangco (page does not exist)">
        Ramon Cojuangco
       </a>
       , late businessman and chairman of
       <a href="/wiki/PLDT" title="PLDT">
        PLDT
       </a>
       , and father of Antonio "Tony Boy" Cojuangco (who would eventually succeed his father in the telecommunications company), both happened to be cousins of
       <a href="/wiki/Corazon_Aquino" title="Corazon Aquino">
        Corazon Aquino
       </a>
       . These associates of Marcos then used these as fronts to
       <a href="/wiki/Money_laundering" title="Money laundering">
        launder proceeds
       </a>
       from institutionalized graft and corruption in the different national governmental agencies as "
       <a href="/wiki/Crony_capitalism" title="Crony capitalism">
        crony capitalism
       </a>
       " for personal benefit. Graft and corruption via bribery,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Racketeering" title="Racketeering">
        racketeering
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Embezzlement" title="Embezzlement">
        embezzlement
       </a>
       became more prevalent during this era. Marcos also silenced the free press, making the press of the state propaganda the only legal one, which was a common practice for governments around the world that sought to fight communism.
      </p>
      <p>
       By 1977, the armed forces had quadrupled and over 60,000 Filipinos had been arrested for political reasons. In 1981, Vice President
       <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">
        George H. W. Bush
       </a>
       praised Marcos for his "adherence to democratic principles and to the democratic processes".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BushMarcos_143-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BushMarcos-143">
         [b]
        </a>
       </sup>
       No American military or politician in the 1970s ever publicly questioned the authority of Marcos to help fight communism in South East Asia.
      </p>
      <p>
       Marcos and his close
       <a href="/wiki/Rolex_12" title="Rolex 12">
        Rolex 12
       </a>
       associates like
       <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ponce_Enrile" title="Juan Ponce Enrile">
        Juan Ponce Enrile
       </a>
       used their powers to settle scores against old rivals such as the Lopezes who were always opposed to the Marcos administration. Enrile and the Lopezes (
       <a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Lopez_Sr." title="Eugenio Lopez Sr.">
        Eugenio Lopez Sr.
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Lopez_Jr." title="Eugenio Lopez Jr.">
        Eugenio Lopez Jr.
       </a>
       ) were
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Harvard" title="Harvard">
        Harvard
       </a>
       -educated Filipino leaders. Leading opponents such as Senators
       <a href="/wiki/Benigno_Aquino_Jr." title="Benigno Aquino Jr.">
        Benigno Aquino Jr.
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jose_Diokno" title="Jose Diokno">
        Jose Diokno
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jovito_Salonga" title="Jovito Salonga">
        Jovito Salonga
       </a>
       and many others were imprisoned for months or years. This practice considerably alienated the support of the old social and economic elite and the media, who criticized the Marcos administration endlessly.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
        <a href="#cite_note-144">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The old social and economic elite, all of whom relied on trade and agricultural and industrial exports to the United States such as the families of Enrile, Lopez, Cojuangco, and Aquino, sought a free-market economy. At this point, Marcos controlled both the oligarchy and the oligopoly.
      </p>
      <p>
       Between 1972 and 1976, Marcos increased the size of the Philippine military from 65,000 to 270,000 personnel, in response to the fall of South Vietnam to the communists and the growing tide of communism in South East Asia. Military officers were placed on the
       <a href="/wiki/Board_of_directors" title="Board of directors">
        boards
       </a>
       of a variety of media corporations, public utilities, development projects, and other private corporations, most of whom were highly educated and well-trained graduates of the Philippine Military Academy. At the same time, Marcos made efforts to foster the growth of a domestic weapons manufacturing industry and heavily increased military spending.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
        <a href="#cite_note-145">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       From the declaration of martial law in 1972 until 1983 the U.S. government provided $2.5 billion in bilateral military and economic aid to the Marcos regime, and about $5.5 billion through multilateral institutions such as the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">
        World Bank
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
        <a href="#cite_note-146">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In a 1979
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Senate" title="United States Senate">
        U.S. Senate
       </a>
       report it was stated that U.S. officials were aware, as early as 1973, that Philippine government agents were in the United States to harass Filipino dissidents. In June 1981, two anti-Marcos labor activists were assassinated outside of a union hall in Seattle. On at least one occasion,
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">
        CIA
       </a>
       agents blocked
       <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">
        FBI
       </a>
       investigations of Philippine agents.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
        <a href="#cite_note-147">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Many human rights abuses were attributed to the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Constabulary" title="Philippine Constabulary">
        Philippine Constabulary
       </a>
       which was then headed by future president
       <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Ramos" title="Fidel Ramos">
        Fidel Ramos
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Integrated_Civilian_Home_Defense_Forces" title="Integrated Civilian Home Defense Forces">
        Civilian Home Defense Force
       </a>
       , a precursor of Civilian Armed Forces Geographical Unit (CAFGU), was organized by President Marcos to battle with the communist and Islamic insurgency problem, has particularly been accused of notoriously inflicting human right violations on leftists, the NPA, Muslim insurgents, and rebels against the Marcos government.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_37-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-auto-37">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, under martial law the Marcos administration was able to reduce violent urban crime, collect unregistered firearms, and suppress communist insurgency in some areas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
        <a href="#cite_note-148">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Marcos regime instituted a mandatory youth organization, known as the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kabataang_Barangay" title="Kabataang Barangay">
        Kabataang Barangay
       </a>
       , which was led by Marcos's eldest daughter Imee. Presidential Decree 684, enacted in April 1975, required that all youths aged 15 to 18 be sent to remote rural camps and do volunteer work.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
        <a href="#cite_note-149">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
        <a href="#cite_note-150">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Along with Marcos, members of his
       <a href="/wiki/Rolex_12" title="Rolex 12">
        Rolex 12
       </a>
       circle like Defense Minister
       <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ponce_Enrile" title="Juan Ponce Enrile">
        Juan Ponce Enrile
       </a>
       , Chief of Staff of the Philippine Constabulary
       <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Ramos" title="Fidel Ramos">
        Fidel Ramos
       </a>
       , and Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces of the Philippines
       <a href="/wiki/Fabian_Ver" title="Fabian Ver">
        Fabian Ver
       </a>
       were the chief administrators of martial law from 1972 to 1981, and the three remained President Marcos's closest advisers until he was ousted in 1986. Other peripheral members of the
       <a href="/wiki/Rolex_12" title="Rolex 12">
        Rolex 12
       </a>
       included
       <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Cojuangco_Jr." title="Eduardo Cojuangco Jr.">
        Eduardo "Danding" Cojuangco Jr.
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Lucio_Tan" title="Lucio Tan">
        Lucio Tan
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Normalization_of_ties_with_Communist_China_and_effort_to_isolate_local_communist_rebels">
        Normalization of ties with Communist China and effort to isolate local communist rebels
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Normalization of ties with Communist China and effort to isolate local communist rebels">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Marcos recognized the need to established a peaceful relationship with
       <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">
        China
       </a>
       . In his 1969 State of the Nation Address, he said:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
        <a href="#cite_note-151">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>
        We, in Asia must strive toward a modus vivendi with Red China. I reiterate this need, which is becoming more urgent each day. Before long, Communist China will have increased its striking power a thousand fold with a sophisticated delivery system for its nuclear weapons. We must prepare for that day. We must prepare to coexist peaceably with Communist China.
       </p>
       <div class="templatequotecite">
        —
        <cite>
         Ferdinand Marcos, January 1969
        </cite>
       </div>
      </blockquote>
      <p>
       Prior to 1975, the Philippine government maintained a close relationship with the
       <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">
        Kuomintang
       </a>
       -ruled Chinese government which fled to
       <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">
        Taiwan
       </a>
       (Republic of China), despite the
       <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Revolution" title="Chinese Communist Revolution">
        Chinese Communist Victory
       </a>
       in 1949, and saw Communist
       <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">
        China
       </a>
       (People's Republic of China) as a security threat due to China's financial and military support of Communist rebels in the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
        <a href="#cite_note-152">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In June 1975, President Marcos went to the People's Republic of China and signed a Joint Communiqué normalizing relations between the Philippines and China. Among other things, the Communiqué recognizes that "there is but one China and that Taiwan is an integral part of Chinese territory…" In turn, Chinese Prime Minister
       <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Enlai" title="Zhou Enlai">
        Zhou Enlai
       </a>
       also pledged that China would not intervene in the internal affairs of the Philippines nor will it seek to impose its policies in Asia, a move which isolated the local communist movement that China had financially and militarily supported.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
        <a href="#cite_note-153">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-web.stanford.edu_154-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-web.stanford.edu-154">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Washington_Post" title="Washington Post">
        Washington Post
       </a>
       in an interview with former Philippine Communist Party Officials, revealed that, "they (local communist party officials) wound up languishing in China for 10 years as unwilling "guests" of the (Chinese) government, feuding bitterly among themselves and with the party leadership in the Philippines".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-washingtonpost.com_123-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-washingtonpost.com-123">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The government subsequently captured NPA leaders
       <a href="/wiki/Bernabe_Buscayno" title="Bernabe Buscayno">
        Bernabe Buscayno
       </a>
       in 1976 and
       <a href="/wiki/Jose_Maria_Sison" title="Jose Maria Sison">
        Jose Maria Sison
       </a>
       in 1977.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-web.stanford.edu_154-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-web.stanford.edu-154">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="First_parliamentary_elections_after_martial_law_declaration">
        First parliamentary elections after martial law declaration
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: First parliamentary elections after martial law declaration">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_parliamentary_election,_1978" title="Philippine parliamentary election, 1978">
        Philippine parliamentary election, 1978
       </a>
       was held on April 7, 1978 for the election of the 166 (of the 208) regional representatives to the
       <a href="/wiki/Interim_Batasang_Pambansa" title="Interim Batasang Pambansa">
        Interim Batasang Pambansa
       </a>
       (the nation's first parliament). The elections were participated by several parties including Ninoy Aquino's newly formed party, the
       <b>
        <a href="/wiki/Lakas_ng_Bayan" title="Lakas ng Bayan">
         Lakas ng Bayan
        </a>
       </b>
       (LABAN) and the regime's party known as the
       <b>
        <a href="/wiki/Kilusang_Bagong_Lipunan" title="Kilusang Bagong Lipunan">
         Kilusang Bagong Lipunan
        </a>
       </b>
       (KBL).
      </p>
      <p>
       The Ninoy Aquino's LABAN party fielded 21 candidates for the Metro Manila area including Ninoy himself and Alex Boncayao, who later was associated with Filipino communist death squad Alex Boncayao Brigade
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
        <a href="#cite_note-155">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roces_156-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Roces-156">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       that killed U.S. army captain
       <a href="/wiki/James_N._Rowe" title="James N. Rowe">
        James N. Rowe
       </a>
       . All of the party's candidates, including Ninoy, lost in the election.
      </p>
      <p>
       Marcos's KBL party won 137 seats, while Pusyon Bisaya led by
       <a href="/wiki/Hilario_Davide_Jr." title="Hilario Davide Jr.">
        Hilario Davide Jr.
       </a>
       , who later became the Minority Floor Leader, won 13 seats.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Prime_Minister">
        Prime Minister
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Prime Minister">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       In 1978, the position returned when Ferdinand Marcos became Prime Minister. Based on
       <i>
        Article 9
       </i>
       of the 1973 constitution, it had broad executive powers that would be typical of modern prime ministers in other countries. The position was the official head of government, and the commander-in-chief of the armed forces. All of the previous powers of the President from the 1935 Constitution were transferred to the newly restored office of Prime Minister. The Prime Minister also acted as head of the National Economic Development Authority. Upon his re-election to the Presidency in 1981, Marcos was succeeded as Prime Minister by an American-educated leader and
       <a href="/wiki/Wharton_School_of_the_University_of_Pennsylvania" title="Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania">
        Wharton
       </a>
       graduate,
       <a href="/wiki/Cesar_Virata" title="Cesar Virata">
        Cesar Virata
       </a>
       , who was elected as an Assemblyman (Member of the Parliament) from Cavite in 1978. He is the eponym of the Cesar Virata School of Business, the business school of the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Philippines_Diliman" title="University of the Philippines Diliman">
        University of the Philippines Diliman
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cabinet_under_martial_law">
        Cabinet under martial law
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Cabinet under martial law">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div>
       <table class="multicol" role="presentation" style="border-collapse: collapse; padding: 0; border: 0; background:transparent; width:100%;">
        <tr>
         <td style="width:50%; text-align:left; vertical-align:top;">

            </td>

             </b>

            </td>
           </tr>
           <tr>
            <td>
             <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Philippines)" title="Department of Foreign Affairs (Philippines)">

             </a>
            </td>

             <b>
              <a href="/wiki/Carlos_P._Romulo" title="Carlos P. Romulo">

              </a>
             </b>
            </td>
            <td>
             1978–1984
            </td>
           </tr>
           <tr>
            <td>
            </td>
            <td>
             <b>
              <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Collantes" title="Manuel Collantes">
               Manuel Collantes
              </a>
             </b>
            </td>
            <td>
             1984
            </td>
           </tr>
           <tr>
            <td>
            </td>
            <td>
             <b>
              <a href="/wiki/Arturo_Tolentino" title="Arturo Tolentino">
               Arturo Tolentino
              </a>
             </b>
            </td>
            <td>
             1984–1985
            </td>
           </tr>
           <tr>
            <td>
            </td>
            <td>
             <b>
              Pacifico Castro
             </b>
            </td>
            <td>
             1985–1986
            </td>
           </tr>
           <tr>
            <td>
             <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Finance_(Philippines)" title="Department of Finance (Philippines)">
              Minister of Finance
             </a>
            </td>
            <td>
             <b>
              <a href="/wiki/Cesar_Virata" title="Cesar Virata">
               Cesar Virata
              </a>
             </b>
            </td>
            <td>
             1978–1986
            </td>
           </tr>

      <h3>
       <span id="Third_term_.281981.E2.80.931986.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Third_term_(1981–1986)">
        Third term (1981–1986)
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Third term (1981–1986)">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="infobox" style="width:22em;width:26em; padding: 0px;">
       <caption>
        <small>
         Economy of the Philippines under
        </small>
        <br/>
        President Ferdinand Marcos
        <br/>
        <small>
         1982–1985
        </small>
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background: lightblue;">
         Population
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal;">
         <b>
          1985
         </b>
        </th>
        <td>
         <span class="mwe-math-element">
          <span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
           <math alttext="{\displaystyle \approx }" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
            <semantics>
             <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
              <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
               <mo>
                ≈
                <!-- ≈ -->
               </mo>
              </mstyle>
             </mrow>
             <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
              {\displaystyle \approx }
             </annotation>
            </semantics>
           </math>
          </span>
          <img alt="\approx " aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6f58f4c2b73283ce8a5ad28fb3746f2a8c998789" style="vertical-align: 0.125ex; margin-bottom: -0.297ex; width:1.808ex; height:1.509ex;"/>
         </span>
         54.67 million
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background: lightblue;">
         Gross Domestic Product
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal;">
         <b>
          1982
         </b>
        </th>
        <td>
         <img alt="Decrease" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/11px-Decrease2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/17px-Decrease2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/22px-Decrease2.svg.png 2x" title="Decrease" width="11"/>
         <a href="/wiki/Philippine_peso" title="Philippine peso">
          ₱
         </a>
         1,857 billion (US$217.45 billion)
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal;">
         <b>
          1985
         </b>
        </th>
        <td>
         <img alt="Decrease" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/11px-Decrease2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/17px-Decrease2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/22px-Decrease2.svg.png 2x" title="Decrease" width="11"/>
         ₱1,537 million (US$82.59 billion)
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal;">
         <b>
          Growth rate, 1982–85 average
         </b>
        </th>
        <td>
         -2.3%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background: lightblue;">
         Per capita income
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal;">
         <b>
          1982
         </b>
        </th>
        <td>
         <img alt="Decrease" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/11px-Decrease2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/17px-Decrease2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/22px-Decrease2.svg.png 2x" title="Decrease" width="11"/>
         ₱37,000
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal;">
         <b>
          1985
         </b>
        </th>
        <td>
         <img alt="Decrease" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/11px-Decrease2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/17px-Decrease2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/22px-Decrease2.svg.png 2x" title="Decrease" width="11"/>
         ₱26,000
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background: lightblue;">
         <a href="/wiki/Exchange_rate" title="Exchange rate">
          Exchange rates
         </a>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         USD1 = ₱18.61
         <br/>
         ₱1 = USD0.05
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         <i>
          Sources
         </i>
         :
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govph_66-3">
          <a href="#cite_note-govph-66">
           [65]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malacanang.gov.ph_97-2">
          <a href="#cite_note-malacanang.gov.ph-97">
           [96]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wb_118-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-wb-118">
           [117]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_presidential_election_and_referendum,_1981" title="Philippine presidential election and referendum, 1981">
        Philippine presidential election and referendum, 1981
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MarcosinWashington1983.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="832" data-file-width="502" height="282" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/MarcosinWashington1983.jpg/170px-MarcosinWashington1983.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/MarcosinWashington1983.jpg/255px-MarcosinWashington1983.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/MarcosinWashington1983.jpg/340px-MarcosinWashington1983.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MarcosinWashington1983.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         President Ferdinand E. Marcos in Washington in 1983.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>
        We love your adherence to democratic principles and to the democratic process, and we will not leave you in isolation.
       </p>
       <div class="templatequotecite">
        —
        <cite>
         U.S. Vice President
         <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">
          George H. W. Bush
         </a>
         during Ferdinand E. Marcos inauguration, June 1981
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
          <a href="#cite_note-159">
           [157]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BushMarcos_143-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-BushMarcos-143">
           [b]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </cite>
       </div>
      </blockquote>
      <p>
       On June 16, 1981, six months after the lifting of martial law, the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_presidential_election_and_referendum,_1981" title="Philippine presidential election and referendum, 1981">
        first presidential election in twelve years
       </a>
       was held. President Marcos ran and won a massive victory over the other candidates.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Steinberg_160-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Steinberg-160">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The major opposition parties, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nationalists_Democratic_Organizations" title="United Nationalists Democratic Organizations">
        United Nationalists Democratic Organizations
       </a>
       (UNIDO), a coalition of opposition parties and LABAN, boycotted the elections.
      </p>
      <p>
       After the lifting of Martial Law, the pressure on the Communist CPP-NPA alleviated. The group able to return to urban areas and form relationships with legal opposition organizations, and became increasingly successful attacks against the government throughout the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-web.stanford.edu_154-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-web.stanford.edu-154">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The violence inflicted by the communists reached its peak in 1985 with 1,282 military and police deaths and 1,362 civilian deaths.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-web.stanford.edu_154-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-web.stanford.edu-154">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="Aquino.27s_assassination">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Aquino's_assassination">
        Aquino's assassination
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Aquino's assassination">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Benigno_Aquino_Jr." title="Assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr.">
        Assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr.
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       On August 21, 1983, opposition leader
       <a href="/wiki/Benigno_Aquino_Jr." title="Benigno Aquino Jr.">
        Benigno Aquino Jr.
       </a>
       was assassinated on the tarmac at
       <a href="/wiki/Ninoy_Aquino_International_Airport" title="Ninoy Aquino International Airport">
        Manila International Airport
       </a>
       . He had returned to the Philippines after three years in exile in the United States, where he had a heart bypass operation to save his life after Marcos allowed him to leave the Philippines to seek medical care. Prior to his heart surgery, Ninoy, along with his two co-accused,
       <a href="/wiki/New_People%27s_Army" title="New People's Army">
        NPA
       </a>
       leaders
       <a href="/wiki/Bernabe_Buscayno" title="Bernabe Buscayno">
        Bernabe Buscayno
       </a>
       (Commander Dante) and Lt. Victor Corpuz, was sentenced to death by a military commission on charges of murder, illegal possession of firearms and subversion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-asianjournalusa.com_134-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-asianjournalusa.com-134">
         [133]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A few months before his assassination, Ninoy was decided to go back to the Philippines after his research fellowship from
       <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">
        Harvard University
       </a>
       had expired. The opposition blamed Marcos directly for the assassination while others blamed the military and his wife, Imelda. Popular speculations pointed to three suspects; the first was Marcos himself through his trusted military chief Fabian Ver; the second theory pointed to his wife Imelda who had her own burning ambition now that her ailing husband seemed to be getting weaker, and the third theory was that
       <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Cojuangco_Jr." title="Eduardo Cojuangco Jr.">
        Danding Cojuangco
       </a>
       planned the assassination because of his own political ambitions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inquirerOrderedHit_161-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-inquirerOrderedHit-161">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The 1985 acquittals of Chief of Staff General
       <a href="/wiki/Fabian_Ver" title="Fabian Ver">
        Fabian Ver
       </a>
       as well as other high-ranking military officers charged with the crime were widely seen as a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Whitewash_(censorship)" title="Whitewash (censorship)">
        whitewash
       </a>
       and a miscarriage of justice.
      </p>
      <p>
       On November 22, 2007, Pablo Martinez, one of the convicted suspects in the assassination of Ninoy Aquino Jr. alleges that it was Ninoy Aquino Jr.'s relative, Danding Cojuangco, cousin of his wife Corazon Cojuangco Aquino, who ordered the assassination of Ninoy Aquino Jr. while Marcos was recuperating from his kidney transplant. Martinez also alleges only he and Galman knew of the assassination, and that Galman was the actual shooter, which is not corroborated by other evidence of the case.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
        <a href="#cite_note-162">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Impeachment_attempt">
        Impeachment attempt
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Impeachment attempt">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       In August 1985, 56 Assemblymen signed a resolution calling for the
       <a href="/wiki/Impeachment" title="Impeachment">
        impeachment
       </a>
       of President Marcos for alleged diversion of U.S. aid for personal use,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
        <a href="#cite_note-163">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
       citing a July 1985
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/San_Jose_Mercury_News" title="San Jose Mercury News">
         San Jose Mercury News
        </a>
       </i>
       exposé of the Marcos's multimillion-dollar investment and property holdings in the United States.
      </p>
      <p>
       The properties allegedly amassed by the First Family were the Crown Building, Lindenmere Estate, and a number of residential apartments (in New Jersey and New York), a shopping center in New York, mansions (in London, Rome and Honolulu), the Helen Knudsen Estate in Hawaii and three condominiums in San Francisco, California.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Assembly also included in the complaint the misuse and misapplication of funds "for the construction of the
       <a href="/wiki/Manila_Film_Center" title="Manila Film Center">
        Manila Film Center
       </a>
       , where X-rated and pornographic films
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       are exhibited, contrary to public morals and Filipino customs and traditions." The impeachment attempt gained little real traction, however, even in the light of this incendiary charge; the committee to which the impeachment resolution was referred did not recommend it, and any momentum for removing Marcos under constitutional processes soon died.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2014)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Physical_decline">
        Physical decline
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Physical decline">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/People_Power_Revolution" title="People Power Revolution">
        People Power Revolution
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       During his third term, Marcos's health deteriorated rapidly due to kidney ailments, as a complication of a chronic autoimmune disease
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Lupus_erythematosus" title="Lupus erythematosus">
         lupus erythematosus
        </a>
       </i>
       . He had a kidney transplant in August 1983, and when his body rejected the first kidney transplant, he had a second transplant in November 1984.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-articles.latimes.com_164-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-articles.latimes.com-164">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Marcos's regime was sensitive to publicity of his condition; a palace physician who alleged that during one of these periods Marcos had undergone a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kidney_transplant" title="Kidney transplant">
        kidney transplant
       </a>
       was shortly afterwards found murdered. Police said he was kidnapped and slain by communist rebels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-articles.latimes.com_164-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-articles.latimes.com-164">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many people questioned whether he still had capacity to govern, due to his grave illness and the ballooning political unrest.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
        <a href="#cite_note-165">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       With Marcos ailing, his powerful wife, Imelda, emerged as the government's main public figure. Marcos dismissed speculations of his ailing health as he used to be an avid golfer and fitness buff who liked showing off his physique.
      </p>
      <p>
       By 1984, U.S. President
       <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">
        Ronald Reagan
       </a>
       started distancing himself from the Marcos regime that he and previous American presidents had strongly supported even after Marcos declared martial law. The United States, which had provided hundreds of millions of dollars in aid, was crucial in buttressing Marcos's rule over the years,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
        <a href="#cite_note-166">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
       although during the
       <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">
        Carter administration
       </a>
       the relationship with the U.S. had soured somewhat when President Jimmy Carter targeted the Philippines in his
       <a href="/wiki/Human_rights" title="Human rights">
        human rights
       </a>
       campaign.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Snap_election.2C_revolution">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Snap_election,_revolution">
        Snap election, revolution
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Snap election, revolution">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_presidential_election,_1986" title="Philippine presidential election, 1986">
        Philippine presidential election, 1986
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/People_Power_Revolution" title="People Power Revolution">
        People Power Revolution
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       In late 1985, in the face of escalating public discontent and under pressure from foreign allies, Marcos called a "
       <a href="/wiki/Snap_election" title="Snap election">
        snap election
       </a>
       " with more than a year left in his term. He selected
       <a href="/wiki/Arturo_Tolentino" title="Arturo Tolentino">
        Arturo Tolentino
       </a>
       as his running mate. The opposition to Marcos united behind two American-educated leaders, Aquino's widow,
       <a href="/wiki/Corazon_Aquino" title="Corazon Aquino">
        Corazon
       </a>
       , and her running mate,
       <a href="/wiki/Salvador_Laurel" title="Salvador Laurel">
        Salvador Laurel
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
        <a href="#cite_note-167">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
        <a href="#cite_note-168">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       It was during this time that Marcos's World War II medals for fighting the Japanese Occupation was first questioned by the foreign press. During a campaign in Manila's
       <a href="/wiki/Tondo,_Manila" title="Tondo, Manila">
        Tondo
       </a>
       district, Marcos retorted:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
        <a href="#cite_note-169">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>
        You who are here in Tondo and fought under me and who were part of my guerrilla organization—you answer them, these crazy individuals, especially the foreign press. Our opponents say Marcos was not a real guerrilla. Look at them. These people who were collaborating with the enemy when we were fighting the enemy. Now they have the nerve to question my war record. I will not pay any attention to their accusation.
       </p>
       <div class="templatequotecite">
        —
        <cite>
         Ferdinand Marcos, January 1986
        </cite>
       </div>
      </blockquote>
      <p>
       Marcos was referring to both Presidential candidate Corazon Aquino's father-in-law
       <a href="/wiki/Benigno_Aquino_Sr." title="Benigno Aquino Sr.">
        Benigno Aquino Sr.
       </a>
       and Vice Presidential Candidate Salvador Laurel's father,
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_P._Laurel" title="José P. Laurel">
        José P. Laurel
       </a>
       , who were leaders of the
       <a href="/wiki/KALIBAPI" title="KALIBAPI">
        KALIBAPI
       </a>
       , a puppet political party that collaborated with the Japanese during the
       <a href="/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_the_Philippines" title="Japanese occupation of the Philippines">
        Japanese occupation of the Philippines
       </a>
       . Both were arrested and charged for treason after the war.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foreign_Policy_in_Focus_170-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Foreign_Policy_in_Focus-170">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The elections were held on February 7, 1986.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NSM_171-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NSM-171">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The official election canvasser, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commission_on_Elections" title="Commission on Elections">
        Commission on Elections
       </a>
       (COMELEC), declared Marcos the winner. The final tally of the COMELEC had Marcos winning with 10,807,197 votes against Aquino's 9,291,761 votes. On the other hand, the partial 69% tally of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Movement_for_Free_Elections" title="National Movement for Free Elections">
        National Movement for Free Elections
       </a>
       (NAMFREL), an accredited poll watcher, had Aquino winning with 7,502,601 votes against Marcos's 6,787,556 votes. Cheating was reported on both sides.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
        <a href="#cite_note-172">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This electoral exercise was marred by widespread reports of violence and tampering of election results.
      </p>
      <p>
       Despite common knowledge that Marcos cheated the elections, some claim that Marcos is the one that had been cheated by NAMFREL because his Solid North votes were transmitted very late to the tabulation center at the PICC. Two Namfrel volunteers were hanged in Ilocos. The Ilocano votes were enough to overwhelm Cory's lead in Metro Manila and other places.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Manila_Times_173-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Manila_Times-173">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The alleged fraud culminated in the walkout of 35 COMELEC computer technicians to protest the manipulation of the official election results to favor Ferdinand Marcos. The walkout of computer technicians was led by Linda Kapunan
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-militaryIntervention1986197_174-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-militaryIntervention1986197-174">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the technicians were protected by
       <a href="/wiki/Reform_the_Armed_Forces_Movement" title="Reform the Armed Forces Movement">
        Reform the Armed Forces Movement (RAM)
       </a>
       officers led by her husband Lt. Col. Eduardo "Red" Kapunan. RAM, led by Lt. Col.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gringo_Honasan" title="Gringo Honasan">
        Gregorio "Gringo" Honasan
       </a>
       and backed by Enrile had plotted a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coup_d%27etat" title="Coup d'etat">
        coup d'etat
       </a>
       to seize Malacañang and kill Marcos and his family.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gringoPlot_175-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-gringoPlot-175">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The failed election process gave a decisive boost to the "
       <a href="/wiki/People_Power_Revolution" title="People Power Revolution">
        People Power
       </a>
       movement." Enrile and Ramos would later abandon Marcos's 'sinking ship' and seek protection behind the 1986
       <a href="/wiki/People_Power_Revolution" title="People Power Revolution">
        People Power Revolution
       </a>
       , backed by fellow-American educated
       <a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Lopez_Jr." title="Eugenio Lopez Jr.">
        Eugenio Lopez Jr.
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jaime_Augusto_Zobel_de_Ayala" title="Jaime Augusto Zobel de Ayala">
        Jaime Augusto Zobel de Ayala
       </a>
       , and the old political and economic elites. At the height of the revolution, Juan Ponce Enrile revealed that a purported and well-publicized ambush attempt against him years earlier was in fact faked, in order for Marcos to have a pretext for imposing martial law. However, Marcos never ceased to maintain that he was the duly elected and proclaimed president of the Philippines for a fourth term, but unfairly and illegally deprived of his right to serve it. On February 25, 1986, rival presidential inaugurations were held,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
        <a href="#cite_note-176">
         [174]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but as Aquino supporters overran parts of Manila and seized state broadcaster
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PTV-4" title="PTV-4">
        PTV-4
       </a>
       , Marcos was forced to flee.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
        <a href="#cite_note-177">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Fleeing_from_the_Philippines_to_Hawaii">
        Fleeing from the Philippines to Hawaii
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Fleeing from the Philippines to Hawaii">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       At 15:00
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Standard_Time" title="Philippine Standard Time">
        PST
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GMT%2B8" title="GMT+8">
        GMT+8
       </a>
       ) on February 25, 1986, Marcos talked to
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Senate" title="United States Senate">
        United States Senator
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Paul_Laxalt" title="Paul Laxalt">
        Paul Laxalt
       </a>
       , a close associate of the United States President, Ronald Reagan, asking for advice from the
       <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">
        White House
       </a>
       . Laxalt advised him to "cut and cut cleanly", to which Marcos expressed his disappointment after a short pause.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
        <a href="#cite_note-178">
         [176]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the afternoon, Marcos talked to
       <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ponce_Enrile" title="Juan Ponce Enrile">
        Enrile
       </a>
       , asking for safe passage for him and his family, and included his close allies like General Ver. Finally, at 9:00 p.m., the Marcos family was transported by four
       <a href="/wiki/Sikorsky_S-61R" title="Sikorsky S-61R">
        Sikorsky HH-3E
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Helicopter" title="Helicopter">
        helicopters
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Halperin_179-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Halperin-179">
         [177]
        </a>
       </sup>
       to
       <a href="/wiki/Clark_Air_Base" title="Clark Air Base">
        Clark Air Base
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Angeles,_Philippines" title="Angeles, Philippines">
        Angeles City
       </a>
       , Pampanga, about 83 kilometers north of Manila, before boarding
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Air_Force" title="United States Air Force">
        US Air Force
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/C-130" title="C-130">
        C-130
       </a>
       planes bound for
       <a href="/wiki/Andersen_Air_Force_Base" title="Andersen Air Force Base">
        Andersen Air Force Base
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Guam" title="Guam">
        Guam
       </a>
       , and finally to
       <a href="/wiki/Hickam_Air_Force_Base" title="Hickam Air Force Base">
        Hickam Air Force Base
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">
        Hawaii
       </a>
       where Marcos arrived on February 26.
      </p>
      <p>
       As per the official 23-page US Customs record, the two C-141 transport planes that carried the Marcos family and their closest allies had 23 wooden crates; 12 suitcases and bags, and various boxes, whose contents included enough clothes to fill 67 racks; 413 pieces of jewelry; 24 gold bricks, inscribed “To my husband on our 24th anniversary”; and more than 27m Philippine pesos in freshly printed notes. The jewelry included 70 pairs of jewel-studded cufflinks; an ivory statue of the infant Jesus with a silver mantle and a diamond necklace. The total value of these items was $15 millon.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-daview_180-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-daview-180">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Meanwhile, when protestors stormed Malacañang Palace shortly after their departure, it was famously discovered that Imelda had left behind over 2,700 pairs of shoes in her closet.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
        <a href="#cite_note-181">
         [179]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" title="Roman Catholic Church">
        Catholic
       </a>
       hierarchy and Manila's
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_class" title="Middle class">
        middle class
       </a>
       were crucial to the success of the massive crusade, but only within Metro Manila because no mass demonstrations or protests against Marcos occurred in the provinces and islands of Visayas and Mindanao.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Economy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Marcos_visit_Reagan_1982.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="491" data-file-width="750" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Marcos_visit_Reagan_1982.jpg/220px-Marcos_visit_Reagan_1982.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Marcos_visit_Reagan_1982.jpg/330px-Marcos_visit_Reagan_1982.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Marcos_visit_Reagan_1982.jpg/440px-Marcos_visit_Reagan_1982.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Marcos_visit_Reagan_1982.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos on a walk with U.S. President
         <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">
          Ronald Reagan
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       To help finance a number of economic development projects, the Marcos government borrowed large amounts of money from international lenders.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boyce-1993-p10_182-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Boyce-1993-p10-182">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
        <a href="#cite_note-183">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/External_debt_of_the_Philippines" title="External debt of the Philippines">
        External debt of the Philippines
       </a>
       rose more than 70-fold from $360 million in 1962 to $26.2 billion in 1985,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
        <a href="#cite_note-184">
         [182]
        </a>
       </sup>
       making the Philippines one of the most indebted countries in Asia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boyce-1993-p10_182-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Boyce-1993-p10-182">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Philippine Annual Gross Domestic Product grew from $5.27 billion in 1964 to $37.14 billion in 1982, a year prior to the assassination of Ninoy Aquino. The GDP went down to $30.7 billion in 1985, after two years of economic recession brought about by political instability following Ninoy's assassination.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-data.worldbank.org_185-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-data.worldbank.org-185">
         [183]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A sizable amount of this money went to the Marcos family and friends in the form of behest loans
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       As a former colony of the United States, the Philippines was heavily reliant on the American economy to purchase agricultural goods such as sugar,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Larkinsugar_186-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Larkinsugar-186">
         [184]
        </a>
       </sup>
       tobacco, coconut, bananas, and pineapple
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Quirinosugar_187-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Quirinosugar-187">
         [185]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nadeausugar_188-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Nadeausugar-188">
         [186]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and US corporations prospered.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="Economy_during_martial_law_.281973.E2.80.931980.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy_during_martial_law_(1973–1980)">
        Economy during martial law (1973–1980)
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Economy during martial law (1973–1980)">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       According to World Bank Data, the Philippine's Annual Gross Domestic Product quadrupled from $8 billion in 1972 to $32.45 billion in 1980, while debt stood at US$17.2 billion by the end of 1980.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-data.worldbank.org_185-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-data.worldbank.org-185">
         [183]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nberc9047_189-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nberc9047-189">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Indeed, according to the U.S.-based Heritage Foundation, the Philippines enjoyed its best economic development since 1945 between 1972 and 1979.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
        <a href="#cite_note-190">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The economy grew amidsts two severe global oil shocks following the
       <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">
        1973 oil crisis
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/1979_energy_crisis" title="1979 energy crisis">
        1979 energy crisis
       </a>
       – oil price was $3 / barrel in 1973 and $39.5 in 1979, or a growth of 1200%. By the end of 1979, debt was still manageable, with debt to Debt-GNP ratio about the same as South Korea, according to th US National Bureau of Economic Research.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nberc9047_189-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-nberc9047-189">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
