       Foreign capital was invited to invest in certain industrial projects. They were offered incentives, including tax exemption privileges and the privilege of bringing out their profits in foreign currencies. One of the most important economic programs in the 1980s was the
       <i>
        Kilusang Kabuhayan at Kaunlaran
       </i>
       (Movement for Livelihood and Progress). This program was started in September 1981. It aimed to promote the economic development of the
       <a href="/wiki/Barangay" title="Barangay">
        barangays
       </a>
       by encouraging its residents to engage in their own livelihood projects. The government's efforts resulted in the increase of the nation's economic growth rate to an average of six percent or seven percent from 1970 to 1980.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
        <a href="#cite_note-191">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="Economy_after_martial_law_.281981.E2.80.931985.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy_after_martial_law_(1981–1985)">
        Economy after martial law (1981–1985)
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Economy after martial law (1981–1985)">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Heads_of_State_Cancun_Summit_1981.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="433" data-file-width="650" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Heads_of_State_Cancun_Summit_1981.jpg/220px-Heads_of_State_Cancun_Summit_1981.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Heads_of_State_Cancun_Summit_1981.jpg/330px-Heads_of_State_Cancun_Summit_1981.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Heads_of_State_Cancun_Summit_1981.jpg/440px-Heads_of_State_Cancun_Summit_1981.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Heads_of_State_Cancun_Summit_1981.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Marcos at the
         <a href="/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Summit" title="North–South Summit">
          North–South Summit
         </a>
         on International Cooperation and Development in Cancun alongside other world leaders including
         <a href="/wiki/Indira_Gandhi" title="Indira Gandhi">
          I. Gandhi
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Mitterrand" title="François Mitterrand">
          F. Mitterrand
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">
          R. Reagan
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Thatcher" title="Margaret Thatcher">
          M. Thatcher
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Kurt_Waldheim" title="Kurt Waldheim">
          K. Waldheim
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Zhao_Ziyang" title="Zhao Ziyang">
          Zhao Ziyang
         </a>
         ; October 23, 1981.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Philippine economy, heavily reliant on exports to the United States, suffered a great decline after the Aquino assassination in August 1983 because Filipino business and political leaders who studied in Harvard, Yale, and other US universities began lobbying American and foreign firms to discourage them from investing in the Philippines. This was taking place at the same time that China was beginning to accept free-market capitalism and American businesses were jockeying to establish manufacturing plants in China. The political troubles of the Philippines hindered the entry of foreign investments, and foreign banks stopped granting loans to the Philippine government. In an attempt to launch a national economic recovery program and despite his growing isolation from American businesses, Marcos negotiated with foreign creditors including the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Bank_for_Reconstruction_and_Development" title="International Bank for Reconstruction and Development">
        International Bank for Reconstruction and Development
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">
        World Bank
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">
        International Monetary Fund
       </a>
       (IMF), for a restructuring of the country's foreign debts – to give the Philippines more time to pay the loans. Marcos ordered a cut in government expenditures and used a portion of the savings to finance the
       <i>
        Sariling Sikap
       </i>
       (Self-Reliance), a livelihood program he established in 1984.
      </p>
      <p>
       However, the economy continued to shrink despite the government's recovery efforts due to a number of reasons. Most of the so-called government development programs failed to materialize. Government funds were often siphoned off by Marcos or his cronies. American investors were discouraged by the Filipino economic elite who were against the corruption that by now had become endemic in the Marcos regime.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-albert_192-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-albert-192">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The failure of the recovery program was further augmented by civil unrest, rampant graft and corruption within the government, and Marcos's lack of credibility. The unemployment rate increased from 6.25% in 1972 to 11.058% in 1985.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
        <a href="#cite_note-193">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Considering the severe 1984–1985 recession, the Philippine economy annual growth rate from 1972 to 1985 of 3.4% is significantly lower than the 5.4% growth rate achieved by other countries in ASEAN (Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore) in the same time period.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-truthAboutEconomy_30-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-truthAboutEconomy-30">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Creation_of_a_credit_bureau">
        Creation of a credit bureau
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Creation of a credit bureau">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <p>
       In 1981, Ferdinand Marcos issued
       <i>
        Letter of Instructions No. 1107
       </i>
       mandating the Central Bank of the Philippines to analyze the probability of establishing and funding the operation of a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Credit_bureau_in_the_Philippines" title="Credit bureau in the Philippines">
        credit bureau in the Philippines
       </a>
       due to the disturbing increase of failures on corporate borrowers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194">
        <a href="#cite_note-194">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In adherence to the order,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_the_Philippines" title="Central Bank of the Philippines">
        Central Bank of the Philippines
       </a>
       organized the Credit Information Exchange System under the department of Loans and Credit. It was created to engage in collating, developing and analyzing credit information on individuals, institutions, business entities and other business concerns. It aims to develop and undertake the continuing exchange of credit data within its members and subscribers and to provide an impartial source of credit information for debtors, creditors and the public. On April 14, 1982,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Credit_Information_Bureau,_Inc." title="Credit Information Bureau, Inc.">
        Credit Information Bureau, Inc.
       </a>
       was incorporated as a non-stock, non-profit corporation. CIBI was created pursuant to LOI No. 1107 dated February 16, 1981 and was further strengthened by PD No. 1941 which recognizes and supports CIBI as a suitable
       <a href="/wiki/Credit_bureau" title="Credit bureau">
        credit bureau
       </a>
       to promote the development and maintenance of rational and efficient credit processes in the financial system and in the economy as a whole. In 1997, Credit Information Bureau, Inc. was incorporated and transformed into a private entity and became
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIBI_Information,_Inc." title="CIBI Information, Inc.">
        CIBI Information, Inc.
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIBI" title="CIBI">
        CIBI
       </a>
       is a provider of information and intelligence for business, credit and individuals.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
        <a href="#cite_note-195">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The company also supplies compliance reports before accrediting suppliers, industry partners and even hiring professionals.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
        <a href="#cite_note-196">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_controversies">
        Economic controversies
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Economic controversies">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       According to the book
       <i>
        The Making of the Philippines
       </i>
       by Frank Senauth (p. 103):
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
        <a href="#cite_note-197">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <blockquote>
       <p>
        "Marcos himself diverted large sums of government money to his party's campaign funds. Between 1972 and 1980, the average monthly income of wage workers had fallen by 20%. By 1981, the wealthiest 10% of the population was receiving twice as much income as the bottom 60%.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Morada-1998-p554_198-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Morada-1998-p554-198">
          [196]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </p>
      </blockquote>
      <p>
       The country's total external debt rose from US$2.3 billion in 1970 to US$26.2 billion in 1985 during Marcos's term. Marcos's critics charged that policies have become debt-driven with rampant corruption and plunder of public funds by Marcos and his cronies. This held the country under a debt-servicing crisis which is expected to be fixed by only 2025. Critics have pointed out an elusive state of the country's development as the period is marred by a sharp devaluing of the Philippine Peso from 3.9 to 20.53. The overall economy experienced a slower growth GDP per capita, lower wage conditions and higher unemployment especially towards the end of Marcos's term after the 1983–1984 recession. Some of Marcos's critics claimed that poverty incidence grew from 41% in the 1960s at the time Marcos took the Presidency to 59% when he was removed from power,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
        <a href="#cite_note-199">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">
        <a href="#cite_note-200">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nberc9047_189-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-nberc9047-189">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
        <a href="#cite_note-201">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
        <a href="#cite_note-202">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
        <a href="#cite_note-203">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       From 1972 to 1980, agricultural production fell by 30%. After declaring martial law in 1972, Marcos promised to implement agrarian reforms. However, the land reforms served largely to undermine Marcos's landholder opponents, not to lessen inequality in the countryside,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
        <a href="#cite_note-204">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and encouraged conversion to cash tenancy and greater reliance on farm workers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
        <a href="#cite_note-205">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Under Marcos, timber products were among the nation's top exports but little attention was paid to the environmental impacts of deforestation as cronies never complied with reforestation agreements. By the early 1980s, forestry collapsed because most of the Philippines' accessible forests had been depleted—of the 12 million hectares of forestland, about 7 million had been left barren."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grafStaggering3_206-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-grafStaggering3-206">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
        <a href="#cite_note-207">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       While the book claimed that agricultural production declined by 30% in the 1970s and suggested that timber exports were growing in the same period, an article published by the World Bank on Philippine Agriculture says that crops (rice, corn, coconut, sugar), livestock and poultry and fisheries grew at an average rate of 6.8%, 3% and 4.5%, respectively from 1970 to 1980, and the forestry sector actually declined by an annual average rate of 4.4% through the 1970s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">
        <a href="#cite_note-208">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Despite claims made by the book that land reforms served largely to undermine Marcos's landholder opponents, Marcos's government did not distribute to small farmers his political rival Ninoy Aquino's family's 6,453 hectare
       <a href="/wiki/Hacienda_Luisita" title="Hacienda Luisita">
        Hacienda Luisita
       </a>
       plantation, the biggest in the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
        <a href="#cite_note-209">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
        <a href="#cite_note-210">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       By 1960 the
       <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Foundation" title="Rockefeller Foundation">
        Rockefeller
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ford_Foundation" title="Ford Foundation">
        Ford
       </a>
       Foundations had worked with the
       <a href="/wiki/Carlos_P._Garcia" title="Carlos P. Garcia">
        Garcia administration
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UP_College_of_Agriculture" title="UP College of Agriculture">
        UP College of Agriculture
       </a>
       to establish the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Rice_Research_Institute" title="International Rice Research Institute">
        International Rice Research Institute
       </a>
       (IRRI) in
       <a href="/wiki/Los_Ba%C3%B1os,_Laguna" title="Los Baños, Laguna">
        Los Baños, Laguna
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chandler1992_211-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Chandler1992-211">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        (
        <span>
         p7
        </span>
        )
       </sup>
       signaling the rise of the
       <a href="/wiki/Green_Revolution" title="Green Revolution">
        Green Revolution
       </a>
       (industrialized, chemical agriculture) to the Philippines.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rowlatt20161201_212-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Rowlatt20161201-212">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the late '60s, the Marcos administration took advantage of IRRI's new "miracle rice" cultivar (
       <a href="/wiki/IR8" title="IR8">
        IR8
       </a>
       ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rowlatt20161201_212-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Rowlatt20161201-212">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
       promoting its use throughout the Philippines. While this resulted in annual rice production in the Philippines increasing from 3.7 to 7.7 million tons in two decades and made the Philippines a rice exporter for the first time in the 20th century,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
        <a href="#cite_note-213">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
        <a href="#cite_note-214">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the switch to IR8 required more fertilizers and pesticides. This and other related reforms resulted in high profits for transnational corporations, but were generally harmful to small, peasant farmers who were often pushed into poverty.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
        <a href="#cite_note-215">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights_abuses">
        Human rights abuses
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Human rights abuses">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg">
          <img alt="[icon]" data-file-height="31" data-file-width="44" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          <b>
           This section needs expansion
          </b>
          .
          <small>
           You can help by
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">
            adding to it
           </a>
           .
          </small>
          <small>
           <i>
            (July 2017)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       As many student activists like
       <a href="/wiki/Edgar_Jopson" title="Edgar Jopson">
        Edgar Jopson
       </a>
       and Rigoberto Tiglao, farmers like
       <a href="/wiki/Bernabe_Buscayno" title="Bernabe Buscayno">
        Bernabe Buscayno
       </a>
       , journalists like
       <a href="/wiki/Satur_Ocampo" title="Satur Ocampo">
        Satur Ocampo
       </a>
       , legal political opposition (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ninoy_Aquino" title="Ninoy Aquino">
        Ninoy Aquino
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
        <a href="#cite_note-216">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and fellow candidate in 1978 election Alex Boncayao
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roces_156-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Roces-156">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       ), and priest and nuns joined or developed relationships with the
       <a href="/wiki/CPP%E2%80%93NPA%E2%80%93NDF_rebellion" title="CPP–NPA–NDF rebellion">
        CPP/NDF/NPA
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
        <a href="#cite_note-217">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
       many farmers,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
        <a href="#cite_note-218">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
       student protesters,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iSawMartialLaw_219-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-iSawMartialLaw-219">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
       leftists,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_37-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-auto-37">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       political opponents,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
       journalists and members of the media
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mediaAndMartialLaw_221-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mediaAndMartialLaw-221">
         [219]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-writersJournalists_222-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-writersJournalists-222">
         [220]
        </a>
       </sup>
       accused of being members or sympathizing with the
       <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Philippines" title="Communist Party of the Philippines">
        CPP
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/New_People%27s_Army" title="New People's Army">
        NPA
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Moro_National_Liberation_Front" title="Moro National Liberation Front">
        MNLF
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
        <a href="#cite_note-223">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
       or of plotting against the government were frequent targets of human rights violations. Victims would simply be rounded up with no arrest warrant nor reading of prisoners' rights and kept indefinitely locked up with no charges filed against them.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In a keynote speech at the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_East" title="University of the East">
        University of the East
       </a>
       , journalist Raissa Robles described how anyone could just be arrested (or abducted) with ease through pre-signed Arrest Search and Seizure Orders (ASSO),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whyWeShouldWorry_225-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-whyWeShouldWorry-225">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which allowed the military or police to detain victims on trumped up charges or unclear allegations according to
       <a href="/wiki/Rappler" title="Rappler">
        Rappler
       </a>
       research.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pcUnderMarcos_226-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-pcUnderMarcos-226">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Anybody could be picked up at anytime for any reason by the military or the police, according to Raissa's husband, journalist Alan Robles.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whatMartialLawWasLike_38-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-whatMartialLawWasLike-38">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
        <a href="#cite_note-227">
         [225]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A 1976
       <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">
        Amnesty International
       </a>
       report had listed 88 government torturers, including members of the Philippine Constabulary and the Philippine Army, which was respectively under the direct control of Major General Fidel V. Ramos and Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-amnestyInternational1975_19-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-amnestyInternational1975-19">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
        <a href="#cite_note-228">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to torture victim Rigoberto Tiglao, nearly all of the human rights abuses President Marcos has been accused of were undertaken by Philippine Constabulary units, especially through its national network of “Constabulary Security Units,” whose heads reported directly to Fidel V. Ramos. The most dreaded of these was the Manila-based 5th Constabulary Security Unit (CSU) which featured the dreaded torturer Lt. Rodolfo Aguinaldo,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hartfordMcCoy_20-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-hartfordMcCoy-20">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       credited with capturing most of the Communist Party leaders including Jose Ma. Sison and the communist's Manila-Rizal Regional Committee he headed,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-manilatimes.net_229-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-manilatimes.net-229">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/Metrocom_Intelligence_and_Security_Group" title="Metrocom Intelligence and Security Group">
        Metrocom Intelligence and Security Group (MISG)
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pcUnderMarcos_226-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-pcUnderMarcos-226">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
       under the command of Col. Rolando Abadilla,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hartfordMcCoy_20-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-hartfordMcCoy-20">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the Intelligence Service, Armed Forces of the Philippines (ISAFP).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There are various statistics for human rights abuses committed during the Marcos regime.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Task_Force_Detainees_of_the_Philippines" title="Task Force Detainees of the Philippines">
        Task Force Detainees of the Philippines
       </a>
       has recorded:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karinyoMilitar_230-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-karinyoMilitar-230">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        2,668 incidents of arrests
       </li>
       <li>
        398 disappearances
       </li>
       <li>
        1,338
        <i>
         salvagings
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        128 frustrated
        <i>
         salvagings
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        1,499 killed or wounded in massacres
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Amnesty International reports:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-batasMilitar_231-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-batasMilitar-231">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        70,000 imprisoned
       </li>
       <li>
        34,000 tortured
       </li>
       <li>
        3,240 killed
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Historian
       <a href="/wiki/Alfred_W._McCoy" title="Alfred W. McCoy">
        Alfred McCoy
       </a>
       gives a figure of 3,257 recorded
       <a href="/wiki/Extrajudicial_killing" title="Extrajudicial killing">
        extrajudicial killings
       </a>
       by the military from 1975 to 1985, 35,000 tortured and 70,000 incarcerated.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hartfordMcCoy_20-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-hartfordMcCoy-20">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factChecking3257_232-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-factChecking3257-232">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The newspaper
       <i>
        Bulatlat
       </i>
       (lit. "to open carelessly") places the number of victims of arbitrary arrest and detention at 120,000, the extrajudicial execution of activists under martial law at 1,500 and
       <i>
        Karapatan
       </i>
       (a local human rights group)'s records show 759 involuntarily disappeared with their bodies never found.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
        <a href="#cite_note-233">
         [231]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In addition to these, up to 10,000
       <a href="/wiki/Moro_people" title="Moro people">
        Moro Muslims
       </a>
       were
       <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Marcos#Muslim_Massacres" title="Ferdinand Marcos">
        killed in massacres
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Army" title="Philippine Army">
        Philippine Army
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Constabulary" title="Philippine Constabulary">
        Philippine Constabulary
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Ilaga" title="Ilaga">
        Ilaga
       </a>
       pro-government paramilitary group.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pcijMindanaoMemoryMassacres_234-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-pcijMindanaoMemoryMassacres-234">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Abductions">
        Abductions
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Abductions">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg">
          <img alt="[icon]" data-file-height="31" data-file-width="44" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          <b>
           This section needs expansion
          </b>
          .
          <small>
           You can help by
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">
            adding to it
           </a>
           .
          </small>
          <small>
           <i>
            (July 2017)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Victims were often taken to military "Safehouses",
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-martialLawVictimHealing_235-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-martialLawVictimHealing-235">
         [233]
        </a>
       </sup>
       a euphemism for hidden places of torture,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mostUnsafe_236-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mostUnsafe-236">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
       often blindfolded.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-detentionAndTorture_237-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-detentionAndTorture-237">
         [235]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In a document titled "Open Letter to the Filipino People," martial law martyr
       <a href="/wiki/Edgar_Jopson" title="Edgar Jopson">
        Edgar "Edjop" Jopson
       </a>
       described safehouses as such: "Safehouses usually have their windows always shut tight. They are usually covered with high walls. One would usually detect [safehouses] through the traffic of motorcycles and cars, going in and out of the house at irregular hours. Burly men, armed with pistols tucked in their waists or in clutch bags, usually drive these vehicles."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-atenistaMarcosTortureMachine_238-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-atenistaMarcosTortureMachine-238">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Torture">
        Torture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Torture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg">
          <img alt="[icon]" data-file-height="31" data-file-width="44" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          <b>
           This section needs expansion
          </b>
          .
          <small>
           You can help by
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">
            adding to it
           </a>
           .
          </small>
          <small>
           <i>
            (July 2017)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Various forms of torture were used by the military, and these forms of torture were usually combined with each other.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Psychological_and_emotional_torture">
        Psychological and emotional torture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Psychological and emotional torture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Among the forms of psychological and emotional torture performed were:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Solitary_confinement" title="Solitary confinement">
         Solitary confinement
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-2">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Victims include
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ninoy_Aquino" title="Ninoy Aquino">
         Ninoy Aquino
        </a>
        , Danilo Vizmanos, CPP/NPA Leaders Lt. Victor Corpuz, Bernabe Buscayno, and Jose Maria "Joma" Sison, and
        <a href="/wiki/Hunters_ROTC" title="Hunters ROTC">
         World War II Hunter's Guerrilla forces
        </a>
        commander
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Terry_Adevoso&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Terry Adevoso (page does not exist)">
         Eleuterio "Terry" Adevoso
        </a>
        , who was accused of plotting a coup.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-4">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
         <a href="#cite_note-239">
          [237]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Sleep_deprivation" title="Sleep deprivation">
         Sleep deprivation
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqSanJuanicoBridge_240-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqSanJuanicoBridge-240">
          [238]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-3">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Victims include Ninoy Aquino and Maria Elena-Ang.
       </li>
       <li>
        Playing loud, repetitive music.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-4">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Victims include Ninoy Aquino.
       </li>
       <li>
        Forcing victims to strip naked.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqSanJuanicoBridge_240-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqSanJuanicoBridge-240">
          [238]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Victims include Virgillo Villegas, Maria Elena Ang, Erlene Dangoy, and Monica Atienza.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-5">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Government units mutilating, cooking and eating the flesh of victims (
        <a href="/wiki/Cannibalism" title="Cannibalism">
         cannibalism
        </a>
        ) in front of their family and friends to sow terror.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
         <a href="#cite_note-241">
          [239]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Physical_torture">
        Physical torture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Physical torture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Physical torture was also often inflicted upon victims. Aside from deadly weapons, implements of torture included water, pliers, thumb tacks, ballpoint pens, and flat irons. Physical torture also took the forms of:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Beatings. Almost all who were tortured were subjected to beatings. Victims include Rigoberto Tiglao,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-manilatimes.net_229-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-manilatimes.net-229">
          [227]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Roland Simbulan, Julius Giron, Macario Tiu, Eugenio Magpantay, Joseph Gatus, Rev. Cesar Taguba, Reynaldo Guillermo, Alejandro Arellano, Charley Palma, Victor Quinto, Pedro de Guzman Jr., Reynaldo Rodriguez, Ma. Cristina Verzola, Armando Teng, Romeo Bayle, Agaton Topacio, Reynaldo Ilao, Erlinda Taruc-Co, Ramon Casiple, Winfiredo Hilao,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-6">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <a href="/wiki/Bernabe_Buscayno" title="Bernabe Buscayno">
         Bernabe Buscayno
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Jose_Maria_Sison" title="Jose Maria Sison">
         Jose Maria Sison
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-5">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4keyCommunists_242-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-4keyCommunists-242">
          [240]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electric_shock#Torture" title="Electric shock">
         Electric Shock
        </a>
        (also known as the
        <a href="/wiki/Meralco" title="Meralco">
         Meralco
        </a>
        Treatment)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-7">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
        - where electric wires were attached to fingers, genitalia, arms or the head of the victim, beatings. Victims include
        <a href="/wiki/Etta_Rosales" title="Etta Rosales">
         Etta Rosales
        </a>
        , Charlie Revilla Palma, Wilfredo Hilao, Romeo Tolio, Reynaldo Guillermo, Alejandro Arellano, Victor Quinto, Pedro de Guzman Jr., Reynaldo Rodriguez, Julius giron, Armando Teng, Santiago Alonzo, Romeo Bayle, Agaton Topacio,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-6">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <a href="/wiki/Neri_Colmenares" title="Neri Colmenares">
         Neri Colmenares
        </a>
        ,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9-5Number_243-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-9-5Number-243">
          [241]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Trinidad Herrera and Marco Palo.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-8">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/San_Juanico_Bridge" title="San Juanico Bridge">
         San Juanico Bridge
        </a>
        or Air Treatment - Victim lies between two cots. If the victim's body falls or sags, he or she would be beaten. Victims include Jose "Pete" Lacaba and Bonifacio Ilagan.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-7">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oneTortureVictim_244-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-oneTortureVictim-244">
          [242]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-9">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Truth_Serum" title="Truth Serum">
         Truth Serum
        </a>
        . Victims include Pete Lacaba, Danilo Vizmanos, Fernando Tayag, Bernardo Escarcha, Julius Giron,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-10">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and Victor Quinto.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-8">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_Roulette" title="Russian Roulette">
         Russian Roulette
        </a>
        - a revolver with one bullet loaded is spun up, aimed at the head of the victim, and then the trigger pulled. Victims include Etta Rosales, Cesar Taguba, Carlos Centenera,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-9">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and Winifredo Hilao and Danilo Vizmanos.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-11">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Pistol-whipping" title="Pistol-whipping">
         Pistol-whipping
        </a>
        - beating with rifle or pistol butts. Victims include Reynaldo Guillermo, Robert sunga, Joseph Gatus, Maria Elena-Ang and Nathan Quimpo.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-10">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Water_cure_(torture)" title="Water cure (torture)">
         Water Cure
        </a>
        (also known as the
        <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Waterworks_and_Sewerage_System" title="Metropolitan Waterworks and Sewerage System">
         Nawasa
        </a>
        Treatment)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-12">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
        - large amounts of water would be forced through the victim's mouth, then forced out by beating. Victims Include
        <a href="/wiki/Judy_Taguiwalo" title="Judy Taguiwalo">
         Judy Taguiwalo
        </a>
        , Guillermo Ponce de Leon, Alfonso Abzagado, Andrew Ocampo, and
        <a href="/wiki/Jose_Maria_Sison" title="Jose Maria Sison">
         Jose Maria Sison
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-11">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4keyCommunists_242-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-4keyCommunists-242">
          [240]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Wet Submarine - victims' heads would be submerged in a toilet full of urine and excrement. Victims include Charlie Palma and Wenifredo Villareal.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-13">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Dry Submarine - victims' heads would be inserted into plastic bags, causing suffocation. Victims include Rolieto Trinidad.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-14">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Strangling" title="Strangling">
         Strangulation
        </a>
        - Done by hand, electric wire or steel bar. Victims include Etta Rosales, Carlos Centenera, Willie Tatanis, Juan Villegas and Reynaldo Rodriguez.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-12">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Ashtray -
        <a href="/wiki/Cigarette" title="Cigarette">
         cigarette
        </a>
        burns would be inflicted on the victim. Victims include Marcelino Tolam Jr., Philip Limjoco, Charley Palma, Ma. Cristina Verzola, Reynaldo Rodriguez
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-13">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Neri Colmenares,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9-5Number_243-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-9-5Number-243">
          [241]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Ernesto Luneta and Peter Villaseñor.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-15">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Flat Iron burns - feet are burned with flat irons. Victims include Cenon Sembrano and Bonfiacio Ilagan.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oneTortureVictim_244-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-oneTortureVictim-244">
          [242]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-14">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Candle burns. Victims include Etta Rosales
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-15">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         Sinusunog na rekado
        </i>
        (burning spices) or Pepper Torture - concentrated peppery substance placed on lips, ears and genitals. Victims include Rolieto Trinidad,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-16">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Meynardo Espeleta.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-16">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and Carlos Yari.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-17">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Animal Treatment - victims are manacled and caged like beasts. Victims include Leandro Manalo, Alexander Arevalo, Manuel Daez, Marcelo Gallarin, romualdo Inductivo, Faustino Samonte, Rodolfo Macasalabang. Others like Cesar Taguba was made to drink his own urine and
        <a href="/wiki/Satur_Ocampo" title="Satur Ocampo">
         Satur Ocampo
        </a>
        was made to eat his own feces.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-17">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Cold Torture - Forcing victims to sit against air conditioners set on maximum while shirtless, or to sit or lie down on blocks of ice while naked (sometimes with electric wires). Victims include Rolieto Trinidad, Nestor Bugayong, Winifredo Hilao,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-18">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Pete Villaseñor and Judy Taguiwalo.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-18">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Food deprivation. Victims include NPA founder
        <a href="/wiki/Jose_Maria_Sison" title="Jose Maria Sison">
         Jose Maria Sison
        </a>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4keyCommunists_242-2">
         <a href="#cite_note-4keyCommunists-242">
          [240]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and Rev. Cesar Taguba.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-19">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         Pompyang
        </i>
        (
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cymbals" title="Cymbals">
         cymbals
        </a>
        ) - ear clapping. Victims include Charlie Revilla and Julius Giron.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-20">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Putting bullets between fingers then squeezing the hands tightly. Victims include Erlene Dangoy.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-21">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sexual_torture">
        Sexual torture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Sexual torture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Rape" title="Rape">
         Rape
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-19">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Victims include Maria Cristina Pargas-Bawagan,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortureVictimsTellSC_245-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortureVictimsTellSC-245">
          [243]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Etta Rosales,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ettaRosalesTorture_246-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-ettaRosalesTorture-246">
          [244]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortureVictimsTellSC_245-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortureVictimsTellSC-245">
          [243]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and Erlene Dangoy.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-22">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gang_Rape" title="Gang Rape">
         Gang Rape
        </a>
        . Victims include Hilda Narciso.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-20">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortureVictimsTellSC_245-2">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortureVictimsTellSC-245">
          [243]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-martialLawVictimHealing_235-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-martialLawVictimHealing-235">
          [233]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Sexual_abuse" title="Sexual abuse">
         Molestation
        </a>
        . Victims include Judy Taguiwalo, Erlinda Taruc-Co
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-21">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and Cristina Pargas.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-23">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Sticks inserted into penises. Victims include Bonifacio Ilagan.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oneTortureVictim_244-2">
         <a href="#cite_note-oneTortureVictim-244">
          [242]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Killings">
        Killings
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Killings">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <h4>
       <span id=".22Salvagings.22">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id='"Salvagings"'>
        "Salvagings"
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title='Edit section: "Salvagings"'>
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg">
          <img alt="[icon]" data-file-height="31" data-file-width="44" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          <b>
           This section needs expansion
          </b>
          .
          <small>
           You can help by
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">
            adding to it
           </a>
           .
          </small>
          <small>
           <i>
            (July 2017)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <table class="wikitable sortable floatright" width="30%">
       <caption>
        Number of "salvage" cases (TFDP)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-24">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tfdpPumipiglas_247-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-tfdpPumipiglas-247">
          [245]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Year
        </th>
        <th>
         No. of cases
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         1980
        </td>
        <td>
         139
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         1981
        </td>
        <td>
         218
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         1982
        </td>
        <td>
         210
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         1983
        </td>
        <td>
         368
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         1984
        </td>
        <td>
         538
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Total
        </th>
        <th>
         1,473
        </th>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Summary executions,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-atenistaMarcosTortureMachine_238-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-atenistaMarcosTortureMachine-238">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with often mutilated bodies, sometimes bearing signs of torture, recovered.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-toYoungFilipinos_248-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-toYoungFilipinos-248">
         [246]
        </a>
       </sup>
       One theory is that the term is derived from the Spanish word
       <i>
        salvaje
       </i>
       (savage).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-onSalvaging_249-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-onSalvaging-249">
         [247]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Mutilated remains were often dumped on roadsides for public display in order to show what happens in "safehouses", to spread a sense of fear and intimidate opponents—turning the Philippines into a theater state of terror.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hartfordMcCoy_20-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-hartfordMcCoy-20">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Anyone could be salvaged - Communist rebels, suspects, innocent civilians and priests included. TFDP documented 1,473 "salvage" cases from 1980 to 1984 alone:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-25">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tfdpPumipiglas_247-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-tfdpPumipiglas-247">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Victims included 16-year-old
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conjugal_Dictatorship" title="Conjugal Dictatorship">
        Luis Manuel “Boyet” Mijares
       </a>
       (tortured brutally, with burn marks, all his nails pulled and removed, 33 ice pick wounds around his body,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-familySecretMijares_250-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-familySecretMijares-250">
         [248]
        </a>
       </sup>
       skull bashed in, eyeballs gouged out, genitals mutilated,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44yearsTooLong_251-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-44yearsTooLong-251">
         [249]
        </a>
       </sup>
       then dropped from a helicopter),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-26">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pamantasan_ng_Lungsod_ng_Maynila" title="Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila">
        Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila
       </a>
       student
       <a href="/wiki/Liliosa_Hilao" title="Liliosa Hilao">
        Liliosa Hilao
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252">
        <a href="#cite_note-252">
         [250]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Imee_Marcos#Torture_and_murder_of_Archimedes_Trajano" title="Imee Marcos">
        Archimedes Trajano
       </a>
       and Juan Escandor.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-27">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Enforced_disappearances">
        Enforced disappearances
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Enforced disappearances">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg">
          <img alt="[icon]" data-file-height="31" data-file-width="44" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          <b>
           This section needs expansion
          </b>
          .
          <small>
           You can help by
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">
            adding to it
           </a>
           .
          </small>
          <small>
           <i>
            (July 2017)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Extrajudicial_killings_and_forced_disappearances_in_the_Philippines" title="Extrajudicial killings and forced disappearances in the Philippines">
        Extrajudicial killings and forced disappearances in the Philippines
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Enforced disappearances, also known
       <i>
        "desaparecidos"
       </i>
       or "the disappeared"—people who suddenly went missing, sometimes without a trace and with bodies never recovered.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-noGraveNoJustice_253-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-noGraveNoJustice-253">
         [251]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Victims include
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conjugal_Dictatorship" title="Conjugal Dictatorship">
        Primitivo "Tibo" Mijares
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44yearsTooLong_251-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-44yearsTooLong-251">
         [249]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Emmanuel Alvarez, Albert Enriquez, Ma. Leticia Ladlad, Hermon Lagman,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44yearsTooLong_251-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-44yearsTooLong-251">
         [249]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Mariano Lopez, Rodelo Manaog, Manuel Ontong, Florencio Pesquesa, Arnulfo Resus, Rosaleo Romano, Carlos Tayag, Emmanuel Yap,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bantayog1999_254-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-bantayog1999-254">
         [252]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Jan Quimpo,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44yearsTooLong_251-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-44yearsTooLong-251">
         [249]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Rizalina Ilagan, Christina Catalla, Jessica Sales and Ramon Jasul.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-andManyDisappeared_255-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-andManyDisappeared-255">
         [253]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Notable_murders">
        Notable murders
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Notable murders">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg">
          <img alt="[icon]" data-file-height="31" data-file-width="44" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          <b>
           This section needs expansion
          </b>
          .
          <small>
           You can help by
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">
            adding to it
           </a>
           .
          </small>
          <small>
           <i>
            (July 2017)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       While the numbers of political detainees went down, the number of people killed rose and spiked in 1981, the year Martial Law was officially lifted by Marcos according to
       <a href="/wiki/Task_Force_Detainees_of_the_Philippines" title="Task Force Detainees of the Philippines">
        Task Force Detainees of the Philippines
       </a>
       . According to Senator
       <a href="/wiki/Jose_Diokno" title="Jose Diokno">
        Jose Diokno
       </a>
       , "As torture (cases) declined, a more terrible tactic emerged; unofficial executions"—suspected dissidents were simply arrested and vanished.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-28">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Murder victims include:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Fr. Zacarias Agatep
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-22">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Senator
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ninoy_Aquino" title="Ninoy Aquino">
         Ninoy Aquino
        </a>
        , August 21, 1983.
        <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Benigno_Aquino_Jr." title="Assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr.">
         Assassinated
        </a>
        on the tarmac of the
        <a href="/wiki/Ninoy_Aquino_International_Airport" title="Ninoy Aquino International Airport">
         Manila International Airport
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        Lorena Barros
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-23">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Wiliam Vincent "Bill" Begg
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-24">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        NPA commander
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Alex_Boncayao&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Alex Boncayao (page does not exist)">
         Alex Boncayao
        </a>
        ,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
         <a href="#cite_note-256">
          [254]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Macliing_Dulag" title="Macliing Dulag">
         Macli-ing Dulag
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        Juan Escandor
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-25">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Fr. Tulio Favali
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-26">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Resteta Fernandez
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-27">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Zoilo Francisco, August 1979. Arrested in Brgy. Doña Anecita,
        <a href="/wiki/Pambujan,_Northern_Samar" title="Pambujan, Northern Samar">
         Pambujan, Northern Samar
        </a>
        . He was decapitated by elements of the 60th PC Battalion, and his stomach slashed open.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-29">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Liliosa_Hilao" title="Liliosa Hilao">
         Liliosa Hilao
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        Antonio "Tonyhil" Hilario
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-28">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Evelio_Javier" title="Evelio Javier">
         Evelio Javier
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Edgar_Jopson" title="Edgar Jopson">
         Edgar Jopson
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Emmanuel_F._Lacaba" title="Emmanuel F. Lacaba">
         Emmanuel "Eman" Lacaba
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        Silver Narciso, Feb. 10, 1979. Arrested by the PC in Bgy. Hitalinga, Artacho,
        <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Samar" title="Eastern Samar">
         Eastern Samar
        </a>
        - interrogated about the presence of NPA rebels, tortured, slashed with a knife, died with 9 wounds and both ears chopped off.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-30">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Soldedad Salvador
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-29">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Noel Cerrudo Tierra
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-30">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Nilo Valerio
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tortyur_220-31">
         <a href="#cite_note-tortyur-220">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Civilian_massacres">
        Civilian massacres
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Civilian massacres">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg">
          <img alt="[icon]" data-file-height="31" data-file-width="44" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          <b>
           This section needs expansion
          </b>
          .
          <small>
           You can help by
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">
            adding to it
           </a>
           .
          </small>
          <small>
           <i>
            (October 2017)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       It is hard to judge the full extent of massacres and atrocities which happened during the Marcos regime due to a heavily censored press at the time.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqWarPeaceValor_257-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-inqWarPeaceValor-257">
         [255]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Some of the civilian massacres include the following:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Guinayangan" title="Guinayangan">
         Guinayangan
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Quezon" title="Quezon">
         Quezon
        </a>
        . Feb. 1, 1981 - coconut farmers marched to air their grievances. Military opened fire on a group of farmers that neared Guinayangan plaza. Two people died and 27 were wounded.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
          [256]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Tudela,_Misamis_Occidental" title="Tudela, Misamis Occidental">
         Tudela, Misamis Occidental
        </a>
        . Aug. 24, 1981 - A
        <a href="/wiki/Subanon_people" title="Subanon people">
         Subanon
        </a>
        family, the Gumapons, were asleep in Sitio Gitason, Barrio Lampasan when paramilitary members of the "Rock Christ", a fanatical pseudo-religious sect, strafed their house. 10 of the 12 persons in the house were killed, including an infant.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
          [256]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Las_Navas,_Northern_Samar" title="Las Navas, Northern Samar">
         Las Navas, Northern Samar
        </a>
        . Sept. 15, 1981 - 18 heavily armed security men of the San Jose Timber Corp. (owned by
        <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ponce_Enrile" title="Juan Ponce Enrile">
         Juan Ponce Enrile
        </a>
        ) who were also members of the Special Forces of the
        <a href="/wiki/Integrated_Civilian_Home_Defense_Forces" title="Integrated Civilian Home Defense Forces">
         Civilian Home Defense Force (CHDF)
        </a>
        and allied with the Lost Command (a paramilitary group pursuing insurgents) ordered residents of Barrio Sag-od to come out of their homes. They opened fire, killing 45 men, women and children. Only 13 inhabitants of Barrio Sag-od survived.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain_224-31">
         <a href="#cite_note-marcosMartialLawNeverAgain-224">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-2">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
          [256]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Culasi,_Antique" title="Culasi, Antique">
         Culasi, Antique
        </a>
        . Dec. 19, 1981 - More than 400 of Culasi's mountain barangays held a rally to raise two issues: complaint against a new Philippine Constabulary company in their area and the reduction of taxes on farm products. The rallyists were warned, but they pushed on. Soldiers opened fire while the rallyists were on the bridge. Five farmers died and several were injured.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-3">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
          [256]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Talugtug,_Nueva_Ecija" title="Talugtug, Nueva Ecija">
         Talugtug, Nueva Ecija
        </a>
        . Jan. 3, 1982 - 5 men in their twenties were rounded up by military elements at around 7pm. The next day, their corpses were found. The military had suspected them to be communist supporters.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-4">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
          [256]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Dumingag,_Zamboanga_del_Sur" title="Dumingag, Zamboanga del Sur">
         Dumingag, Zamboanga del Sur
        </a>
        . Feb. 12, 1982 - Members of the
        <a href="/wiki/Ilaga" title="Ilaga">
         Ilaga
        </a>
        killed 12 persons to avenge the death of their leader who was reportedly killed by the NPA.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-5">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
          [256]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Hinunangan,_Southern_Leyte" title="Hinunangan, Southern Leyte">
         Hinunangan, Southern Leyte
        </a>
        . March 23, 1982 - troopers of the 357th PC company killed 8 people in Masaymon barrio. 6 of the 8 victims were 3–18 years of age.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-6">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
          [256]
