         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Bayog,_Zamboanga_del_Sur" title="Bayog, Zamboanga del Sur">
         Bayog, Zamboanga del Sur
        </a>
        . May 25, 1982 - Airplanes dropped bombs on Barangay Dimalinao as military reprisal against the community because communist rebels killed a soldier two days earlier. Three people died and eight people were injured. Days later, two men from the community were picked up and killed. Months later, the residence of Bayog's
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jesuit" title="Jesuit">
         Jesuit
        </a>
        parish priest was strafed with bullets. He had written letters protesting the torture and harassment of
        <a href="/wiki/Subanon_people" title="Subanon people">
         Subanon
        </a>
        who were suspected to be supporters of armed communists.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-7">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
          [256]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Daet,_Camarines_Norte" title="Daet, Camarines Norte">
         Daet, Camarines Norte
        </a>
        . June 14, 1982 - People from different barrios marched to denounce "fake elections",
        <a href="/wiki/Coco_Levy_Fund_scam" title="Coco Levy Fund scam">
         Cocofed
        </a>
        , and to demand an increase in
        <a href="/wiki/Copra" title="Copra">
         copra
        </a>
        prices. Soldiers opened fire as marchers moved forward. 4 people died on the spot, at least 50 were injured, and 2 of the seriously wounded died 2 months later.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-8">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
          [256]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Pulilan,_Bulacan" title="Pulilan, Bulacan">
         Pulilan, Bulacan
        </a>
        . June 21, 1982 - In a dimly lit house, six peasant organizers were discussing and assessing their work when 25-35 uniformed military men with firearms burst in. While one of them was able to slip away, 5 of the peasants were taken by elements of the 175th PC Company to Pulo in
        <a href="/wiki/San_Rafael,_Bulacan" title="San Rafael, Bulacan">
         San Rafael
        </a>
        town. By midnight, 5 bullet-riddled corpses lay at the municipal hall of San Rafael.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-9">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
          [256]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Labo,_Camarines_Norte" title="Labo, Camarines Norte">
         Labo, Camarines Norte
        </a>
        . June 23, 1982 - Five men were gunned down by soldiers of the 45th Infantry Battalion’s Mabilo detachment to avenge the death of a friend of one of the soldiers in the hands of unidentified gunmen.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-10">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
          [256]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Roxas,
        <a href="/wiki/Zamboanga_del_Norte" title="Zamboanga del Norte">
         Zamboanga del Norte
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-11">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
          [256]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Gapan" title="Gapan">
         Gapan, Nueva Ecija
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-12">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
          [256]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Muslim_massacres">
        Muslim massacres
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Muslim massacres">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg">
          <img alt="[icon]" data-file-height="31" data-file-width="44" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          <b>
           This section needs expansion
          </b>
          .
          <small>
           You can help by
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">
            adding to it
           </a>
           .
          </small>
          <small>
           <i>
            (October 2017)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       The Marcos regime had started to kill hundreds of Moros even before the imposition of Martial Law in 1972.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-abscbnTacubMassacre_259-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-abscbnTacubMassacre-259">
         [257]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Thousands of
       <a href="/wiki/Moro_people" title="Moro people">
        Moro Muslims
       </a>
       were killed during the Marcos regime, prompting them to form insurgent groups and separatist movements such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Moro_National_Liberation_Front" title="Moro National Liberation Front">
        Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF)
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Moro_Islamic_Liberation_Front" title="Moro Islamic Liberation Front">
        Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF)
       </a>
       , which became more radical with time due to atrocities against Muslims.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMuslimsMartialLaw_260-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-inqMuslimsMartialLaw-260">
         [258]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the study
       <i>
        The Liberation Movements in Mindanao: Root Causes and Prospects for Peace
       </i>
       , a doctoral dissertation by Marjanie Salic Macasalong, the number of Moro victims killed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Army" title="Philippine Army">
        Army
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Constabulary" title="Philippine Constabulary">
        Philippine Constabulary
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Ilaga" title="Ilaga">
        Ilaga
       </a>
       (a notorious government-sanctioned
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-veraPalimbangMassacre_261-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-veraPalimbangMassacre-261">
         [259]
        </a>
       </sup>
       terrorist cult known for cannibalism and
       <a href="/wiki/Land_grabbing" title="Land grabbing">
        land grabbing
       </a>
       that served as members of the CHDF)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMartialLawMassacres_258-13">
        <a href="#cite_note-inqMartialLawMassacres-258">
         [256]
        </a>
       </sup>
       reached as high as 10,000 lives.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pcijMindanaoMemoryMassacres_234-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-pcijMindanaoMemoryMassacres-234">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Some of the massacres include:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jabidah_Massacre" title="Jabidah Massacre">
         Jabidah Massacre
        </a>
        in March 1968 with 11 to 68 Moros killed. This is the aftermath of an aborted operation to destabilize
        <a href="/wiki/Sabah" title="Sabah">
         Sabah
        </a>
        ,
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Operation_Merdeka" title="Operation Merdeka">
         Operation Merdeka
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        From 1970 to 1971, pro-government militias like the
        <a href="/wiki/Ilaga" title="Ilaga">
         Ilaga
        </a>
        were behind 21 cases of massacres which left 518 people dead, 184 injured and 243 houses burned down.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMorosRecallMassacres_262-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMorosRecallMassacres-262">
          [260]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pcijMindanaoMemoryMassacres_234-2">
         <a href="#cite_note-pcijMindanaoMemoryMassacres-234">
          [232]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The Tacub Massacre in
        <a href="/wiki/Kauswagan,_Lanao_del_Norte" title="Kauswagan, Lanao del Norte">
         Kauswagan, Lanao del Norte
        </a>
        , 1971 - five truckloads of displaced resident voters were stopped at a military checkpoint in Tacub. People were asked to line up as if in a firing squad, then they were summarily executed in with open fire from armed men. Dozens of bodies were strewn all over the road of the barangay after the incident.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-abscbnTacubMassacre_259-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-abscbnTacubMassacre-259">
          [257]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Manili_massacre" title="Manili massacre">
         Manili massacre
        </a>
        in June 1971, with 70-79 Moros, including women and children, were killed inside a mosque by suspected
        <a href="/wiki/Ilaga" title="Ilaga">
         Ilaga
        </a>
        and Philippine Constabulary
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMorosRecallMassacres_262-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMorosRecallMassacres-262">
          [260]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The Burning of
        <a href="/wiki/Jolo,_Sulu" title="Jolo, Sulu">
         Jolo, Sulu
        </a>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqWarPeaceValor_257-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqWarPeaceValor-257">
          [255]
         </a>
        </sup>
        in February 7–8, 1974, where land, sea and air bombardment by the Armed Forces of the Philippines caused fires and destruction in the central commercial town of Jolo that killed over 1,000 and possibly up to 20,000 civilians.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqJoloToMarawi_263-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqJoloToMarawi-263">
          [261]
         </a>
        </sup>
        It was described as "the worst single atrocity to be recorded in 16 years of the Mindanao conflict" by the April 1986 issue of the Philippines Dispatch.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-philippinesDispatchBurningJolo_264-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-philippinesDispatchBurningJolo-264">
          [262]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Malisbong_Massacre" title="Malisbong Massacre">
         Malisbong Massacre
        </a>
        in September 1974, where about 1,500 male Moros were killed inside a mosque, 3,000 women and children aged 9–60 were detained, and about 300 women raped by the Philippine Constabulary.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMorosRecallMassacres_262-2">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMorosRecallMassacres-262">
          [260]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Pata_Island_massacre#Retaliation" title="Pata Island massacre">
         Pata Island massacre
        </a>
        in 1982 where 3,000
        <a href="/wiki/Taus%C5%ABg_people" title="Tausūg people">
         Tausug
        </a>
        civilians, including women and children, were killed by months of Philippine military artillery shelling.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMorosRecallMassacres_262-3">
         <a href="#cite_note-inqMorosRecallMassacres-262">
          [260]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The Tong Umapoy Massacre in 1983 where a Navy ship opened fire on a passenger boat en route to an athletic event in
        <a href="/wiki/Bongao,_Tawi-Tawi" title="Bongao, Tawi-Tawi">
         Bongao, Tawi-Tawi
        </a>
        . 57 people on board were killed.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-veraPalimbangMassacre_261-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-veraPalimbangMassacre-261">
          [259]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="By_NPA_rebels">
        By NPA rebels
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: By NPA rebels">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Human Rights Violations were also committed by the NPA, which summarily executes “enemies of the people”, who they say were condemned by “people’s courts”.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
        <a href="#cite_note-265">
         [263]
        </a>
       </sup>
       From late 1985 to mid-1986, over 600 communist cadres and activists were killed by their own men in a hunt for “deep penetration agents” who had infiltrated the movement for the military.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ICG2011p5_266-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ICG2011p5-266">
         [264]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cadres were accused by their comrades of being military agents and tortured.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ICG2011p5_266-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ICG2011p5-266">
         [264]
        </a>
       </sup>
       They confessed and implicated others, leading to more torture and kill.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ICG2011p5_266-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-ICG2011p5-266">
         [264]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Family_denial">
        Family denial
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: Family denial">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       On the stories of human rights abuses during the Marcos administration,
       <a href="/wiki/Bongbong_Marcos" title="Bongbong Marcos">
        Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr.
       </a>
       describes them as "self-serving statements by politicians, self-aggrandizement narratives, pompous declarations, and political posturing and propaganda."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mlLateStrongmanSon_267-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mlLateStrongmanSon-267">
         [265]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-enrilesMemoir_268-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-enrilesMemoir-268">
         [266]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Ill-gotten_wealth">
        Ill-gotten wealth
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Ill-gotten wealth">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg">
          <img alt="[icon]" data-file-height="31" data-file-width="44" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          <b>
           This section needs expansion
          </b>
          .
          <small>
           You can help by
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">
            adding to it
           </a>
           .
          </small>
          <small>
           <i>
            (July 2017)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       The Philippine Supreme Court considers all Marcos assets beyond their legally declared earnings/salary to be ill-gotten wealth
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scImeldaMarcosvsRP_269-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-scImeldaMarcosvsRP-269">
         [267]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and such wealth have been forfeited in favor of the government or human rights victims.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270">
        <a href="#cite_note-270">
         [268]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Among the sources of the Marcos wealth are alleged to be from diverted foreign economic aid, US Government military aid (including huge discretionary funds at Marcos disposal as a “reward” for sending some Filipino troops to Vietnam) and kickbacks from public works contracts over a 2-decades-long rule.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-timeTakingTollMartialLawVictims_271-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-timeTakingTollMartialLawVictims-271">
         [269]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1990, Imelda Marcos, the widow of the former Philippine President, was acquitted of charges by a U.S. Jury that she raided the country's treasury and invested the money in the United States.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
        <a href="#cite_note-272">
         [270]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1993, she was convicted of graft in Manila for entering into three unfavorable lease contracts between a Government-run transportation agency and another government-run hospital.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
        <a href="#cite_note-273">
         [271]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1998, the Philippine Supreme Court overturned the previous conviction of Imelda Marcos and acquitted her of corruption charges.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
        <a href="#cite_note-274">
         [272]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2008, Philippine trial court judge Silvino Pampilo acquitted Imelda Marcos, then widow of Ferdinand Marcos, of 32 counts of illegal money transfer
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyTimesImeldaAcquitted_275-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nyTimesImeldaAcquitted-275">
         [273]
        </a>
       </sup>
       from the 1993 graft conviction.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imeldaGraft1993_276-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-imeldaGraft1993-276">
         [274]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2010, she was ordered to repay the Philippine government almost $280,000 for funds taken by Ferdinand Marcos in 1983.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imeldaMarcosFastFacts_277-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-imeldaMarcosFastFacts-277">
         [275]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2012, a US Court of Appeals of the Ninth Circuit upheld a contempt judgement against Imelda and her son Bongbong Marcos for violating an injunction barring them from dissipating their assets, and awarded $353.6 million to human rights victims.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosLosesUSAppeal_278-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosLosesUSAppeal-278">
         [276]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of October 2015, she still faces 10 criminal charges of graft, along with 25 civil cases,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wsj.com_279-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-wsj.com-279">
         [277]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newsinfo.inquirer.net_280-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-newsinfo.inquirer.net-280">
         [278]
        </a>
       </sup>
       down from 900 cases in the 1990s, as most of the cases were dismissed for lack of evidence.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gmanetwork.com_281-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-gmanetwork.com-281">
         [279]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the [Presidential Commission on Good Government|PCGG] and
       <i>
        The Guardian
       </i>
       , Ferdinand Marcos had an accumulated stolen wealth of US $5-10 billion during his presidency from 1965 to 1986, while earning an annual salary equivalent to US $13,500.00.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
        <a href="#cite_note-282">
         [280]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2014, Vilma Bautista, the former secretary of Imelda Marcos was sentenced to prison for conspiring to sell a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monet" title="Monet">
        Monet
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sisley" title="Sisley">
        Sisley
       </a>
       and other masterpiece artworks belonging to the Republic of the Philippines for tens of millions of dollars.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inqMarcosSecretaryMonet_283-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-inqMarcosSecretaryMonet-283">
         [281]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284">
        <a href="#cite_note-284">
         [282]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On May 9, 2016, the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Consortium_of_Investigative_Journalists" title="International Consortium of Investigative Journalists">
        International Consortium of Investigative Journalists
       </a>
       released the searchable database from
       <a href="/wiki/Panama_Papers" title="Panama Papers">
        Panama Papers
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285">
        <a href="#cite_note-285">
         [283]
        </a>
       </sup>
       His two daughters, Imee Marcos Manotoc and Irene Marcos Araneta,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286">
        <a href="#cite_note-286">
         [284]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287">
        <a href="#cite_note-287">
         [285]
        </a>
       </sup>
       have been named, along with his grandsons Fernando Manotoc, Matthew Joseph Manotoc, Ferdinand Richard Manotoc, his son-in-law Gregorio Maria Araneta III,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288">
        <a href="#cite_note-288">
         [286]
        </a>
       </sup>
       including his estranged son-in-law Tommy Manotoc's relatives Ricardo Gabriel Manotoc and Teodoro Kalaw Manotoc.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289">
        <a href="#cite_note-289">
         [287]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On September 3, 2017, President
       <a href="/wiki/Rodrigo_Duterte" title="Rodrigo Duterte">
        Rodrigo Duterte
       </a>
       said the family of the late dictator Ferdinand Marcos is "ready to return" their wealth to the government, possibly through a settlement.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
        <a href="#cite_note-290">
         [288]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On January 2018, a draft House Bill proposing a compromise settlement and immunity for the Marcoses submitted by the late Ferdinand Marcos's legal counsel
       <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Lozano" title="Oliver Lozano">
        Oliver Lozano
       </a>
       was revealed on Social Media
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fbDuterteMarcosHousebill_291-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-fbDuterteMarcosHousebill-291">
         [289]
        </a>
       </sup>
       to have been received by the Duterte government in July 2017.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnnMarcosDealDuterte_292-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cnnMarcosDealDuterte-292">
         [290]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Death_and_burial">
        Death and burial
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Death and burial">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Burial_of_Ferdinand_Marcos" title="Burial of Ferdinand Marcos">
        Burial of Ferdinand Marcos
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ferdinand_E._Marcos_Presidential_Center_sign.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="206" data-file-width="274" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Ferdinand_E._Marcos_Presidential_Center_sign.jpg/220px-Ferdinand_E._Marcos_Presidential_Center_sign.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e0/Ferdinand_E._Marcos_Presidential_Center_sign.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ferdinand_E._Marcos_Presidential_Center_sign.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The body of Ferdinand Marcos was stored in a refrigerated crypt at the
         <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_E._Marcos_Presidential_Center" title="Ferdinand E. Marcos Presidential Center">
          Ferdinand E. Marcos Presidential Center
         </a>
         in Batac, Ilocos Norte until 2016.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In his dying days, Marcos was visited by Vice President
       <a href="/wiki/Salvador_Laurel" title="Salvador Laurel">
        Salvador Laurel
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
        <a href="#cite_note-293">
         [291]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During the meeting with Salvador Laurel, Marcos offered 90% of his possessions back to the Filipino people in exchange for being buried back in the Philippines beside his mother, an offer also disclosed to
       <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Zobel" title="Enrique Zobel">
        Enrique Zobel
       </a>
       . However, Marcos's offer was rebuffed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Corazon_Aquino" title="Presidency of Corazon Aquino">
        Aquino government
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294">
        <a href="#cite_note-294">
         [292]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
        <a href="#cite_note-295">
         [293]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
        <a href="#cite_note-296">
         [294]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Marcos died in
       <a href="/wiki/Honolulu" title="Honolulu">
        Honolulu
       </a>
       on the morning of September 28, 1989, of kidney, heart, and lung ailments. Marcos was interred in a private mausoleum at
       <a href="/wiki/Byodo-In_Temple" title="Byodo-In Temple">
        Byodo-In Temple
       </a>
       on the island of Oahu where his remains were visited daily by the Marcos family, political allies and friends.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Aquino government refused to allow Marcos's body to be brought back to the Philippines. The body was only brought back to the Philippines four years after Marcos's death during the term of President
       <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Ramos" title="Fidel Ramos">
        Fidel Ramos
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297">
        <a href="#cite_note-297">
         [295]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       From 1993 to 2016, his remains were interred inside a refrigerated crypt in
       <a href="/wiki/Ilocos_Norte" title="Ilocos Norte">
        Ilocos Norte
       </a>
       , where his son, Ferdinand Jr., and eldest daughter, Imee have since become the local governor and congressional representative, respectively.
       <a href="/wiki/Bust_of_Ferdinand_Marcos" title="Bust of Ferdinand Marcos">
        A large bust
       </a>
       of Ferdinand Marcos (inspired by
       <a href="/wiki/Mount_Rushmore" title="Mount Rushmore">
        Mount Rushmore
       </a>
       ) was commissioned by the tourism minister,
       <a href="/wiki/Jose_D._Aspiras" title="Jose D. Aspiras">
        Jose Aspiras
       </a>
       , and carved into a hillside in Benguet. It was subsequently destroyed; suspects included left-wing activists, members of a local tribe who had been displaced by construction of the monument, and looters hunting for the legendary
       <a href="/wiki/Yamashita%27s_gold" title="Yamashita's gold">
        Yamashita treasure
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
        <a href="#cite_note-298">
         [296]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Opinion on his burial remains split: 50 percent of the 1,800 respondents of a survey conducted by
       <a href="/wiki/Social_Weather_Stations" title="Social Weather Stations">
        SWS
       </a>
       in February 2016 said Marcos "was worthy to be buried at the Libingan ng Mga Bayani" while the other half rejected a hero's burial, calling him a "thief".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ABS-CBN_299-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ABS-CBN-299">
         [297]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On November 18, 2016, the remains of Marcos was buried at the
       <a href="/wiki/Heroes%27_Cemetery" title="Heroes' Cemetery">
        Heroes' Cemetery
       </a>
       despite opposition from various groups. The burial came as unexpected to many, as the Supreme Court's ruling still allowed 15 days for the opposition to file a motion for reconsideration. On the morning of November 18, using Philippine Armed Forces choppers, his family and their supporters flew his remains from Ilocos to Manila for a private burial.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Marcos_burial_Ateneans_protest.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Marcos_burial_Ateneans_protest.jpg/220px-Marcos_burial_Ateneans_protest.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Marcos_burial_Ateneans_protest.jpg/330px-Marcos_burial_Ateneans_protest.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Marcos_burial_Ateneans_protest.jpg/440px-Marcos_burial_Ateneans_protest.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Marcos_burial_Ateneans_protest.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Students of the
         <a href="/wiki/Ateneo_de_Manila_University" title="Ateneo de Manila University">
          Ateneo de Manila University
         </a>
         along
         <a href="/wiki/Katipunan_Avenue" title="Katipunan Avenue">
          Katipunan Avenue
         </a>
         protesting against the burial of Marcos insisting that the former President is not a hero and a dictator.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Various protest groups formed immediately upon news of the burial. Among those who gathered to opposed the burial was a group of youth. The League of Filipino Students described the transfer of Marcos remains for the eventually successful burial the former president as being done like "a thief in the night." They also criticized the government's involvement in the burial of the former president which they describe as a "fascist dictator". The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kabataan_Partylist" title="Kabataan Partylist">
        Kabataan Partylist
       </a>
       condemn the burial labeling it as a "grave travesty" and as "
       <i>
        galawang Hokage
       </i>
       " (
       <abbr title="literal translation">
        lit.
       </abbr>
       <span style="white-space:nowrap;">
        <i>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hokage" title="Hokage">
          Hokage
         </a>
        </i>
        move;
        <i>
         Hokage
        </i>
        is a high-ranked
        <a href="/wiki/Ninja" title="Ninja">
         ninja
        </a>
        in the
        <i>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Naruto_(anime)" title="Naruto (anime)">
          Naruto
         </a>
        </i>
        anime franchise)
       </span>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300">
        <a href="#cite_note-300">
         [298]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Recognition">
        Recognition
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: Recognition">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="National">
        National
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: National">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PHL_Legion_of_Honor_-_Chief_Commander_BAR.png">
         <img alt="PHL Legion of Honor - Chief Commander BAR.png" data-file-height="60" data-file-width="218" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/PHL_Legion_of_Honor_-_Chief_Commander_BAR.png/45px-PHL_Legion_of_Honor_-_Chief_Commander_BAR.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/PHL_Legion_of_Honor_-_Chief_Commander_BAR.png/68px-PHL_Legion_of_Honor_-_Chief_Commander_BAR.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/PHL_Legion_of_Honor_-_Chief_Commander_BAR.png/90px-PHL_Legion_of_Honor_-_Chief_Commander_BAR.png 2x" width="45"/>
        </a>
        : Chief Commander of the
        <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Legion_of_Honor" title="Philippine Legion of Honor">
         Philippine Legion of Honor
        </a>
        (September 11, 1972)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301">
         <a href="#cite_note-301">
          [299]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Man of the Year 1965, Philippine Free Press (January 1, 1966)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302">
         <a href="#cite_note-302">
          [300]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>

       <span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign">

        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">

        </a>

        </a>
        (July 8, 1976)
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="flagicon">
