        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">
         Indonesia
        </a>
        :
        <a href="/wiki/Orders,_decorations,_and_medals_of_Indonesia" title="Orders, decorations, and medals of Indonesia">
         Star of Indonesia
        </a>
        , First Class (January 12, 1968)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303">
         <a href="#cite_note-303">
          [301]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/45px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">
         Japan
        </a>
        : Grand Cordon of the Supreme
        <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Chrysanthemum" title="Order of the Chrysanthemum">
         Order of the Chrysanthemum
        </a>
        (September 20, 1966)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304">
         <a href="#cite_note-304">
          [302]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="420" data-file-width="840" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Flag_of_Jordan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Jordan.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Flag_of_Jordan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Jordan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Flag_of_Jordan.svg/46px-Flag_of_Jordan.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">
         Jordan
        </a>
        : Grand Collar of the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Order_of_al-Hussein_bin_Ali" title="Order of al-Hussein bin Ali">
         Order of al-Hussein bin Ali
        </a>
        (March 1, 1976)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305">
         <a href="#cite_note-305">
          [303]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="341" data-file-width="512" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Flag_of_the_Order_of_St._John_%28various%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Order_of_St._John_%28various%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Flag_of_the_Order_of_St._John_%28various%29.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Order_of_St._John_%28various%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Flag_of_the_Order_of_St._John_%28various%29.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Order_of_St._John_%28various%29.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_Military_Order_of_Malta" title="Sovereign Military Order of Malta">
         Sovereign Military Order of Malta
        </a>
        : Grand Cross of the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Order_pro_merito_Melitensi" title="Order pro merito Melitensi">
         Order pro merito Melitensi
        </a>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
         <a href="#cite_note-306">
          [304]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Flag_of_Romania_%281965-1989%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Romania_%281965-1989%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Flag_of_Romania_%281965-1989%29.svg/35px-Flag_of_Romania_%281965-1989%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Flag_of_Romania_%281965-1989%29.svg/45px-Flag_of_Romania_%281965-1989%29.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">
         Romania
        </a>
        :
        <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Star_of_the_Romanian_Socialist_Republic" title="Order of the Star of the Romanian Socialist Republic">
         Order of the Star of the Romanian Socialist Republic
        </a>
        (April 9, 1975)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307">
         <a href="#cite_note-307">
          [305]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="2880" data-file-width="4320" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Flag_of_Singapore.svg/23px-Flag_of_Singapore.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Flag_of_Singapore.svg/35px-Flag_of_Singapore.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Flag_of_Singapore.svg/45px-Flag_of_Singapore.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">
         Singapore
        </a>
        :
        <a href="/wiki/Darjah_Utama_Temasek" title="Darjah Utama Temasek">
         Order of Temasek
        </a>
        , First Class (January 15, 1974)
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="750" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Flag_of_Spain_%281945-1977%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain_%281945-1977%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Flag_of_Spain_%281945-1977%29.svg/35px-Flag_of_Spain_%281945-1977%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Flag_of_Spain_%281945-1977%29.svg/45px-Flag_of_Spain_%281945-1977%29.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
         Spain
        </a>
        :
        <ul>
         <li>
          Knight of the Collar of the
          <a href="/wiki/Order_of_Isabella_the_Catholic" title="Order of Isabella the Catholic">
           Order of Isabella the Catholic
          </a>
          (December 22, 1969)
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gov.ph_308-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-gov.ph-308">
            [306]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </li>
         <li>
          Knight Grand Cross of the
          <a href="/wiki/Crosses_of_Military_Merit" title="Crosses of Military Merit">
           Order of Military Merit
          </a>
          - White Decoration (February 18, 1974)
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gov.ph_308-1">
           <a href="#cite_note-gov.ph-308">
            [306]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </li>
        </ul>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_Thailand.svg/23px-Flag_of_Thailand.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_Thailand.svg/35px-Flag_of_Thailand.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_Thailand.svg/45px-Flag_of_Thailand.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">
         Thailand
        </a>
        :
        <ul>
         <li>
          Knight of the Most Auspicious
          <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Rajamitrabhorn" title="Order of the Rajamitrabhorn">
           Order of the Rajamitrabhorn
          </a>
          (January 15, 1968)
         </li>
         <li>
          <a href="/wiki/Thammasat_University" title="Thammasat University">
           Thammasat University
          </a>
          : Honorary degree of
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doctor_of_Laws" title="Doctor of Laws">
           Doctor of Laws
          </a>
          (LLD)
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Honoris_causa" title="Honoris causa">
           honoris causa
          </a>
          (January 15, 1968)
         </li>
        </ul>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Likewise, he and wife, Imelda are credited in 1989 by the
       <a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" title="Guinness World Records">
        Guinness World Records
       </a>
       for the largest-ever theft: USD860.8 million "salted away" identified in April 23, 1986 with total stolen since November 1965, an estimated 5 to 10 billion dollars.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guinness1989_309-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-guinness1989-309">
         [307]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guinness1991_310-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-guinness1991-310">
         [308]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guinness1999_311-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-guinness1999-311">
         [309]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guinness2_312-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-guinness2-312">
         [310]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guinness3_313-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-guinness3-313">
         [311]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314">
        <a href="#cite_note-314">
         [312]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Works">
        Works
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: Works">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure_and_monuments">
        Infrastructure and monuments
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: Infrastructure and monuments">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Starita2jf.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Starita2jf.JPG/220px-Starita2jf.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Starita2jf.JPG/330px-Starita2jf.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Starita2jf.JPG/440px-Starita2jf.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Starita2jf.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/North_Luzon_Expressway" title="North Luzon Expressway">
          North Luzon Expressway
         </a>
         , one of Marcos's infrastructure projects
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Marcos's government built widely publicized infrastructure projects and monuments using foreign currency loans
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theMarcosDebt_315-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-theMarcosDebt-315">
         [313]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and at great taxpayer cost.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theEdificeComplex_316-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-theEdificeComplex-316">
         [314]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gma7edifice_317-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-gma7edifice-317">
         [315]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This focus on infrastructure, which critics saw as a propaganda technique, eventually earned the colloquial label "edifice complex".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theEdificeComplex_316-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-theEdificeComplex-316">
         [314]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gma7edifice_317-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-gma7edifice-317">
         [315]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edifice_318-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-edifice-318">
         [316]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       These including hospitals
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319">
        <a href="#cite_note-319">
         [317]
        </a>
       </sup>
       like the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Heart_Center" title="Philippine Heart Center">
        Philippine Heart Center
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lung_Center_of_the_Philippines" title="Lung Center of the Philippines">
        Lung Center
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/National_Kidney_and_Transplant_Institute" title="National Kidney and Transplant Institute">
        Kidney Center
       </a>
       , transportation infrastructure like
       <a href="/wiki/San_Juanico_Bridge" title="San Juanico Bridge">
        San Juanico Bridge
       </a>
       (formerly Marcos Bridge),
       <a href="/wiki/Pan-Philippine_Highway" title="Pan-Philippine Highway">
        Pan-Philippine Highway
       </a>
       , North Luzon Expressway, South Luzon Expressway,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320">
        <a href="#cite_note-320">
         [318]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Manila_Light_Rail_Transit_System_Line_1" title="Manila Light Rail Transit System Line 1">
        Manila Light Rail Transit (LRT)
       </a>
       , and 17 hydroelectric
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321">
        <a href="#cite_note-321">
         [319]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322">
        <a href="#cite_note-322">
         [320]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_power" title="Geothermal power">
        geothermal power
       </a>
       plants
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-energy.com.ph_323-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-energy.com.ph-323">
         [321]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324">
        <a href="#cite_note-324">
         [322]
        </a>
       </sup>
       to lessen the country's dependency on oil.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325">
        <a href="#cite_note-325">
         [323]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By 1983, the Philippines became the second largest producer of
       <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_power" title="Geothermal power">
        geothermal power
       </a>
       in the world with the commissioning of the Tongonan 1 and Palinpinon 1 geothermal plants.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-energy.com.ph_323-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-energy.com.ph-323">
         [321]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326">
        <a href="#cite_note-326">
         [324]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to UP Economics Professor Dr. Sicat, "a study of infrastructure construction by various presidents shows that Marcos was the president who made the largest infrastructure investment. This is not because he was the longest-serving leader of the country alone. On a per-year basis, he led all the presidents. Only
       <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Ramos" title="Fidel Ramos">
        Fidel Ramos
       </a>
       had bested him in road building for a period of one year".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327">
        <a href="#cite_note-327">
         [325]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On the education front, 47
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328">
        <a href="#cite_note-328">
         [326]
        </a>
       </sup>
       state colleges and universities were built during the Marcos administration, which represents over 40% of all the existing 112 state colleges and universities
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329">
        <a href="#cite_note-329">
         [327]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330">
        <a href="#cite_note-330">
         [328]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in the country. To help transform the country's agricultural-based economy to a
       <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">
        Newly industrialized country
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331">
        <a href="#cite_note-331">
         [329]
        </a>
       </sup>
       he spearheaded the development of 11 heavy industrialization projects
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332">
        <a href="#cite_note-332">
         [330]
        </a>
       </sup>
       including steel, petrochemical,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333">
        <a href="#cite_note-333">
         [331]
        </a>
       </sup>
       cement, pulp and paper mill, and copper smelter.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334">
        <a href="#cite_note-334">
         [332]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cultural and heritage sites like the
       <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Center_of_the_Philippines" title="Cultural Center of the Philippines">
        Cultural Center of the Philippines
       </a>
       , Nayong Pilipino,
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_International_Convention_Center" title="Philippine International Convention Center">
        Philippine International Convention Center
       </a>
       and the disastrous and ill-fated
       <a href="/wiki/Manila_Film_Center" title="Manila Film Center">
        Manila Film Center
       </a>
       were built as well.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Laws">
        Laws
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=54" title="Edit section: Laws">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Likewise, the country crafted a large number of decrees, laws, and edicts during Marcos's term.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-legacy_335-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-legacy-335">
         [333]
        </a>
       </sup>
       From 1972 to 1986, the Marcos Administration codified laws through 2,036 Presidential Decrees,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336">
        <a href="#cite_note-336">
         [334]
        </a>
       </sup>
       an average of 145 per year during the 14-year period. To put this into context, only 14, 12, and 11 laws were passed in 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337">
        <a href="#cite_note-337">
         [335]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A large amount of the laws passed during the term of Marcos remain in force today and are embedded in the country's legal system.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-legacy_335-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-legacy-335">
         [333]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Marcos, together with agriculture minister and
       <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">
        Harvard-educated
       </a>
       Arturo Tanco
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338">
        <a href="#cite_note-338">
         [336]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and later on Salvador Escudero Jr., was instrumental in the
       <a href="/wiki/Green_Revolution" title="Green Revolution">
        Green Revolution
       </a>
       in the Philippines and initiated an agricultural program called Masagana 99, improving agricultural productivity and enabling the country to achieve rice sufficiency in the late 1970s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339">
        <a href="#cite_note-339">
         [337]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340">
        <a href="#cite_note-340">
         [338]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Authored_works">
        Authored works
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=55" title="Edit section: Authored works">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <i>
         National discipline: the key to our future
        </i>
        (1970)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iLib_341-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-iLib-341">
          [339]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         Today's Revolution: Democracy
        </i>
        (1971)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iLib_341-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-iLib-341">
          [339]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         Notes on the New Society of the Philippines
        </i>
        (1973)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iLib_341-2">
         <a href="#cite_note-iLib-341">
          [339]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         Tadhana: the history of the Filipino People
        </i>
        (1977, 1982)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iLib_341-3">
         <a href="#cite_note-iLib-341">
          [339]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         The democratic revolution in the Philippines
        </i>
        (1977)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iLib_341-4">
         <a href="#cite_note-iLib-341">
          [339]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         Five years of the new society
        </i>
        (1978)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iLib_341-5">
         <a href="#cite_note-iLib-341">
          [339]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         President Ferdinand E. Marcos on law, development and human rights
        </i>
        (1978)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iLib_341-6">
         <a href="#cite_note-iLib-341">
          [339]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         President Ferdinand E. Marcos on agrarian reform
        </i>
        (1979)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iLib_341-7">
         <a href="#cite_note-iLib-341">
          [339]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         An Ideology for Filipinos
        </i>
        (1980)
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         An introduction to the politics of transition
        </i>
        (1980)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iLib_341-8">
         <a href="#cite_note-iLib-341">
          [339]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         Marcos's Notes for the
         <a href="/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Summit" title="North–South Summit">
          Cancun Summit
         </a>
         , 1981
        </i>
        (1981)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iLib_341-9">
         <a href="#cite_note-iLib-341">
          [339]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         Progress and Martial Law
        </i>
        (1981)
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         The New Philippine Republic: A Third World Approach to Democracy
        </i>
        (1982)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iLib_341-10">
         <a href="#cite_note-iLib-341">
          [339]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         Toward a New Partnership: The Filipino Ideology
        </i>
        (1983)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iLib_341-11">
         <a href="#cite_note-iLib-341">
          [339]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         A Trilogy on the Transformation of Philippine Society
        </i>
        (1988)
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Reparations">
        Reparations
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=56" title="Edit section: Reparations">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       In 1995, some 10,000 Filipinos won a U.S.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Class-action" title="Class-action">
        class-action
       </a>
       lawsuit filed against the Marcos estate. The claims were filed by victims or their surviving relatives consequent on torture, execution, and disappearances.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342">
        <a href="#cite_note-342">
         [340]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343">
        <a href="#cite_note-343">
         [341]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Government_of_Switzerland" title="Government of Switzerland">
        Swiss government
       </a>
       , initially reluctant to respond to allegations that stolen funds were held in Swiss accounts,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344">
        <a href="#cite_note-344">
         [342]
        </a>
       </sup>
       has returned $684 million of Marcos's stash.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-star_345-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-star-345">
         [343]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346">
        <a href="#cite_note-346">
         [344]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347">
        <a href="#cite_note-347">
         [345]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348">
        <a href="#cite_note-348">
         [346]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Corazon Aquino repealed many of the repressive laws that had been enacted during Marcos's dictatorship. She restored the right of access to
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Habeas_corpus" title="Habeas corpus">
         habeas corpus
        </a>
       </i>
       , repealed anti-labor laws and freed hundreds of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_prisoners" title="Political prisoners">
        political prisoners
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349">
        <a href="#cite_note-349">
         [347]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       From 1989 to 1996, a series of suits were brought before U.S. courts against Marcos and his daughter Imee, alleging that they bore responsibility for executions, torture, and disappearances. A jury in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ninth_Circuit_Court_of_Appeals" title="Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals">
        Ninth Circuit Court
       </a>
       awarded USD2 billion to the plaintiffs and to a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Class_action_lawsuit" title="Class action lawsuit">
        class
       </a>
       composed of human rights victims and their families.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350">
        <a href="#cite_note-350">
         [348]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On June 12, 2008, the
       <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">
        U.S. Supreme Court
       </a>
       (in a 7–2 ruling penned by Justice
       <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Kennedy" title="Anthony Kennedy">
        Anthony Kennedy
       </a>
       in
       <i>
        Republic of the Philippines v. Mariano Pimentel
       </i>
       ) held that: "The judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit is reversed, and the case is remanded with instructions to order the District Court to dismiss the
       <a href="/wiki/Interpleader" title="Interpleader">
        interpleader
       </a>
       action." The court dismissed the interpleader lawsuit filed to determine the rights of 9,500 Filipino human rights victims (1972–1986) to recover USD35 million, part of a USD2 billion judgment in U.S. courts against the Marcos estate, because the Philippines government is an indispensable party, protected by
       <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_immunity" title="Sovereign immunity">
        sovereign immunity
       </a>
       . The Philippines government claimed ownership of the funds transferred by Marcos in 1972 to Arelma S.A., which invested the money with
       <a href="/wiki/Merrill_Lynch" title="Merrill Lynch">
        Merrill Lynch
       </a>
       , Pierce, Fenner &amp; Smith Inc., in New York.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351">
        <a href="#cite_note-351">
         [349]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352">
        <a href="#cite_note-352">
         [350]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353">
        <a href="#cite_note-353">
         [351]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In July 2017, the Philippine Court of Appeals rejected the petition seeking to enforce the United States court decision that awarded the $2 billion in compensation to human rights victims during the term of former President Ferdinand Marcos.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354">
        <a href="#cite_note-354">
         [352]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">
        Legacy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferdinand_Marcos&amp;action=edit&amp;section=57" title="Edit section: Legacy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bust_of_Ferdinand_Marcos,_near_the_town_of_Baguio.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="333" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Bust_of_Ferdinand_Marcos%2C_near_the_town_of_Baguio.jpg/220px-Bust_of_Ferdinand_Marcos%2C_near_the_town_of_Baguio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Bust_of_Ferdinand_Marcos%2C_near_the_town_of_Baguio.jpg/330px-Bust_of_Ferdinand_Marcos%2C_near_the_town_of_Baguio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/de/Bust_of_Ferdinand_Marcos%2C_near_the_town_of_Baguio.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bust_of_Ferdinand_Marcos,_near_the_town_of_Baguio.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Bust_of_Ferdinand_Marcos" title="Bust of Ferdinand Marcos">
          Bust of Ferdinand Marcos
         </a>
         before it was destroyed in 2002.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Marcos left a mixed legacy for future generations. On one hand, many laws written by Marcos are still in force and in effect. Out of thousands of proclamations, decrees, and executive orders, only a few were repealed, revoked, modified or amended.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355">
        <a href="#cite_note-355">
         [353]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On the other, his twenty years in power represent the bloodiest in the history of Philippines, with more extra judicial killings of civic people than those that occurred during parallel Latin American dictators like
       <a href="/wiki/Augusto_Pinochet" title="Augusto Pinochet">
        Pinochet
       </a>
       . More importantly, many people who rose to power under Marcos continued to remain in power or even ascended higher after his exile, thus leaving a further imprint on present-day Filipino affairs. One of these was
       <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Ramos" title="Fidel Ramos">
        Fidel Ramos
       </a>
       , a general promoted by Marcos who supervised many terror killings and tortures, who later switched sides and subsequently fought elections and became president himself.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mccoy_356-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mccoy-356">
         [354]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>
        I often wonder what I will be remembered in history for. Scholar? Military hero? Builder? The new constitution? Reorganization of government? Builder of roads, schools? The green revolution? Uniter of variant and antagonistic elements of our people? He brought light to a dark country? Strong rallying point, or a weak tyrant?
       </p>
       <div class="templatequotecite">
        —
        <cite>
         Ferdinand Marcos
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357">
          <a href="#cite_note-357">
           [355]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </cite>
       </div>
      </blockquote>
      <p>
       Massive foreign loans also enabled Marcos to build more schools, hospitals and infrastructure than all of his predecessors combined,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lacsamana1990p189_10-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-lacsamana1990p189-10">
         [9]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but at great cost. Today, according to Ibon Foundation, a left-leaning think tank that advocated the government to default on its debt, Filipino citizens are still bearing the heavy burden of servicing public debts incurred during Marcos's administration, with ongoing interest payments on the loan schedule by the Philippine government estimated to last until 2025–59 years after Marcos assumed office and 39 years after he was kicked out.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ibonMarcosDept_358-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ibonMarcosDept-358">
         [356]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Corazon Aquino had an opportunity to default and not pay foreign debt incurred during the Marcos administration. However, due to Finance Secretary
       <a href="/wiki/Jaime_Ongpin" title="Jaime Ongpin">
        Jaime Ongpin
       </a>
       's warning
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359">
        <a href="#cite_note-359">
         [357]
        </a>
       </sup>
       on the consequences of a debt
       <a href="/wiki/Default_(finance)" title="Default (finance)">
        default
       </a>
       , which includes isolating the country from the international financial community and hampering the economic recovery, Corazon Aquino honored all the debts incurred during the Marcos Administration,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360">
        <a href="#cite_note-360">
         [358]
        </a>
       </sup>
       contrary to expectations of left-learning organizations like Ibon foundation which advocated for non-payment of debt.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361">
        <a href="#cite_note-361">
         [359]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Jaime Ongpin, who is a brother of Marcos trade minister
       <a href="/wiki/Roberto_Ongpin" title="Roberto Ongpin">
        Roberto Ongpin
       </a>
       , was later dismissed by Cory Aquino and later died in an apparent suicide after "he had been depressed about infighting in Aquino's cabinet and disappointed that the 'People Power' uprising which had toppled dictator Ferdinand Marcos had not brought significant change".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362">
        <a href="#cite_note-362">
         [360]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 2004 Global Transparency Report, Marcos appeared in the list of the World's Most Corrupt Leaders, listed in second place behind
       <a href="/wiki/Suharto" title="Suharto">
        Suharto
       </a>
       , the former President of Indonesia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transparency.org_12-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-transparency.org-12">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363">
        <a href="#cite_note-363">
         [361]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>
        The amount of theft perpetrated by Marcos's regime was probably less than that by Suharto on Indonesia, but harmed our country more because the sums stolen by Marcos were sent out of the country, whereas Suharto's loot mostly were invested in Indonesia.
       </p>
       <div class="templatequotecite">
        —
        <cite>
         Former Senator
         <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Paterno" title="Vicente Paterno">
          Vicente Paterno
         </a>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paterno1_364-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-paterno1-364">
           [362]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </cite>
       </div>
      </blockquote>
      <p>
       According to
       <a href="/wiki/Jovito_Salonga" title="Jovito Salonga">
        Jovito Salonga
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Monopoly" title="Monopoly">
        monopolies
       </a>
       in several vital industries were created and placed under the control of Marcos cronies, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Coconut" title="Coconut">
        coconut
       </a>
       industries (under
       <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Cojuangco_Jr." title="Eduardo Cojuangco Jr.">
        Eduardo Cojuangco Jr.
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ponce_Enrile" title="Juan Ponce Enrile">
        Juan Ponce Enrile
       </a>
       ), the
       <a href="/wiki/Tobacco" title="Tobacco">
        tobacco
       </a>
       industry (under
       <a href="/wiki/Lucio_Tan" title="Lucio Tan">
        Lucio Tan
       </a>
       ), the
       <a href="/wiki/Banana" title="Banana">
        banana
       </a>
       industry (under Antonio Floirendo), the
       <a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">
        sugar
       </a>
       industry (under Roberto Benedicto), and
       <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing" title="Manufacturing">
        manufacturing
       </a>
       (under Herminio Disini and Ricardo Silverio). The Marcos and Romualdez families became owners, directly or indirectly, of the nation's largest corporations, such as the Philippine Long Distance Company (PLDC), of which the present name is
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_Long_Distance_Telephone" title="Philippine Long Distance Telephone">
        Philippine Long Distance Telephone
       </a>
       (PLDT),
       <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Airlines" title="Philippine Airlines">
        Philippine Airlines
       </a>
       (PAL),
       <a href="/wiki/Meralco" title="Meralco">
        Meralco
       </a>
       (an electric company),
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMFTC,_Inc." title="PMFTC, Inc.">
        Fortune Tobacco
       </a>
       , numerous newspapers, radio and TV broadcasting companies (such as
       <a href="/wiki/ABS-CBN" title="ABS-CBN">
        ABS-CBN
       </a>
       ), several banks (most notably the Philippine Commercial and Industrial Bank; PCIBank of the Lopezes [now
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BDO_Unibank" title="BDO Unibank">
        BDO
       </a>
       after merging with Equitable Bank and after BDO acquired the merged
       <a href="/wiki/Equitable_PCI_Bank" title="Equitable PCI Bank">
        Equitable PCI
       </a>
       ]), and
       <a href="/wiki/Real_estate" title="Real estate">
        real estate
       </a>
       in New York, California and Hawaii.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365">
        <a href="#cite_note-365">
         [363]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Aquino government also accused them of skimming off foreign aid and international assistance.
      </p>
      <p>
       During the ICIJ's (International Consortium of Investigative Journalists) expose of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Offshore_leaks" title="Offshore leaks">
        offshore leaks
       </a>
       in April 2013, the name of his eldest daughter,
       <a href="/wiki/Imee_Marcos" title="Imee Marcos">
        Imee Marcos
       </a>
       , appeared on the list of wealthy people involved in offshore financial secrecy. It was revealed that she is hiding parts of her father's ill-gotten wealth in
       <a href="/wiki/Tax_haven" title="Tax haven">
        tax havens
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/British_Virgin_Islands" title="British Virgin Islands">
        British Virgin Islands
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ICIJ_Secret_Files_Expose_366-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ICIJ_Secret_Files_Expose-366">
         [364]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367">
        <a href="#cite_note-367">
         [365]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Comparisons have also been made between Ferdinand Marcos and Lee Kuan Yew's authoritarian style of governance and Singapore's success,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnnLegaciesMarcosLKY_368-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cnnLegaciesMarcosLKY-368">
         [366]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but in his autobiography,
       <i>
        From Third World to First: The Singapore Story: 1965–2000
       </i>
       , Lee relates:
      </p>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>
        It is a soft, forgiving culture. Only in the Philippines could a leader like Ferdinand Marcos, who pillaged his country for over 20 years, still be considered for a national burial. Insignificant amounts of the loot have been recovered, yet his wife and children were allowed to return and engage in politics.
       </p>
       <div class="templatequotecite">
        —
        <cite>
         Lee Kuan Yew
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LKY15thingsPhilStar_369-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-LKY15thingsPhilStar-369">
           [367]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </cite>
       </div>
      </blockquote>
      <p>
       According to
       <a href="/wiki/Presidential_Commission_on_Good_Government" title="Presidential Commission on Good Government">
        Presidential Commission on Good Government
       </a>
       , the Marcos family and their cronies looted so much wealth from the Philippines that, to this day, investigators have difficulty determining precisely how many billions of dollars were stolen.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimesHuntForMarcosBillions_370-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYTimesHuntForMarcosBillions-370">
         [368]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The agency claimed that Marcos stole around $5 to $10 billion from the Philippine treasury.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theDiplomatEndof30_371-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-theDiplomatEndof30-371">
         [369]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marcosMissingMillions_372-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-marcosMissingMillions-372">
         [370]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373">
        <a href="#cite_note-373">
         [371]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374">
        <a href="#cite_note-374">
         [372]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Adjusted for inflation, this would be equivalent to about USD11.16 to USD22.3 billion or over 550 billion to 1.1 trillion Philippine pesos in 2017.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blsInflationCalculator_375-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-blsInflationCalculator-375">
         [373]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>

         <span class="reference-text">

        <li id="cite_note-62">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-62">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.chanrobles.com/cralaw19391.htm" rel="nofollow">
            "CHAN ROBLES VIRTUAL LAW LIBRARY: PHILIPPINE SUPREME COURTDECISIONS ON-LINE"
           </a>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CHAN+ROBLES+VIRTUAL+LAW+LIBRARY%3A+PHILIPPINE+SUPREME+COURTDECISIONS+ON-LINE&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.chanrobles.com%2Fcralaw19391.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AFerdinand+Marcos">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-63">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-63">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Justice Jose P. Laurel penned the
          <i>
           ponencia
          </i>
          (in
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.lawphil.net/judjuris/juri1940/oct1940/gr_l-47388_1940.html" rel="nofollow">
           People vs. Mariano Marcos, et al., 70 Phil. 468
          </a>
          ) with which
          <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_Philippines" title="Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines">
           Chief Justice
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Ram%C3%B3n_Avance%C3%B1a" title="Ramón Avanceña">
           Ramón Avanceña
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/Associate_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_Philippines" title="Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines">
           Justices
          </a>
          Imperial,
          <a href="/wiki/Anacleto_D%C3%ADaz" title="Anacleto Díaz">
           Díaz
          </a>
          and Horilleno all concurred.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-64">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-64">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          See page 32,
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20101227223116/http://www.utoledo.edu/as/pdfs/100years.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            "Archived copy"
           </a>
           <span style="font-size:85%;">
            (PDF)
           </span>
           . Archived from
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.utoledo.edu/as/pdfs/100years.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            the original
           </a>

            (PDF)
           </span>
           on December 27, 2010
           <span class="reference-accessdate">

            <span class="nowrap">

        <li id="cite_note-B.Romualdez_Francia_1988-72">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-B.Romualdez_Francia_1988_72-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          According to Marcos's claims,
          <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Luna" title="Antonio Luna">
           Antonio Luna
          </a>
          is supposedly a "cousin" of Fructuoso Edralin, and was supposedly present during the General's
          <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Luna#Assassination_and_the_Aftermath" title="Antonio Luna">
           assassination at Cabanatuan, Nueva Ecija
          </a>
          .
          <cite class="citation book">
           Romualdez Francia, Beatriz (1988).
           <i>
            Imelda and the clans: A story of the Philippines
           </i>
           . Solar Publishing Corporation.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-9711706319" title="Special:BookSources/978-9711706319">
            978-9711706319
           </a>
           .
          </cite>

        <li id="cite_note-82">

            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Bulatlat piece questioning the Marcos exploits during the war:
          <cite class="citation journal">
           ARTURO P. GARCIA.
           <a class="external text" href="http://bulatlat.com/news/5-19/5-19-bessang.htm" rel="nofollow">
            "The Real Heroes of Bessang Pass"
           </a>
           .
           <i>

           </i>
           .
           <b>

           <a href="#cite_ref-chicagoTribune1_98-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>

         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           Reaves, Joseph A. (September 29, 1989).
           <a class="external text" href="http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-09-29/news/8901180123_1_mr-marcos-ferdinand-edralin-marcos-martial-law/2" rel="nofollow">

           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3_0TBwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PT1225&amp;dq=marcos.+plaza+miranda&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwim5YOk-P3YAhXiQd8KHXZ-CcUQ6AEINzAD#v=onepage&amp;q=marcos.%20plaza%20miranda&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">

           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Mother+Jones+Magazine&amp;rft.pages=35&amp;rft.pub=Mother+Jones&amp;rft.date=1983-06&amp;rft.issn=0362-8841&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DZOYDAAAAMBAJ%26pg%3DPT15&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AFerdinand+Marcos">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-144">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-144">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          For a detailed treatment of corruption under Marcos, see
          <cite class="citation book">
           Chaikin, David &amp; Sharman, Jason Campbell (2009). "The Marcos Kleptocracy".
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=amZkAdGTkl4C&amp;pg=PA153" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             Corruption and money laundering: a symbiotic relationship
            </i>
           </a>
           . Macmillan.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-230-61360-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-230-61360-7">
            978-0-230-61360-7
           </a>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=The+Marcos+Kleptocracy&amp;rft.btitle=Corruption+and+money+laundering%3A+a+symbiotic+relationship&amp;rft.pub=Macmillan&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-230-61360-7&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DamZkAdGTkl4C%26pg%3DPA153&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AFerdinand+Marcos">

        <li id="cite_note-157">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-157">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          The Ministry of Industry and Ministry of Trade were merged by President Ferdinand Marcos in 1981 as the Ministry of Trade and Industry.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-158">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-158">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          The Ministry of Public Works, Transportation and Communications and Ministry of Public Highways were merged by President Ferdinand Marcos in 1981 as the Ministry of Public Works and Highways.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-159">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-159">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation news">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,953029,00.html" rel="nofollow">
            "Philippines: Together Again"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            Time
           </i>
           . July 13, 1981.
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Time&amp;rft.atitle=Philippines%3A+Together+Again&amp;rft.date=1981-07-13&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.time.com%2Ftime%2Fmagazine%2Farticle%2F0%2C9171%2C953029%2C00.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AFerdinand+Marcos">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Steinberg-160">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>

          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-militaryIntervention1986197_174-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20161006015437/http://www.gov.ph/1990/10/03/the-final-report-of-the-fact-finding-commission-iv-military-intervention-in-the-philippines-1986-1987/" rel="nofollow">

           . Greenwood Publishing Group.
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+History+of+the+Philippines&amp;rft.pub=Greenwood+Publishing+Group&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.au=Kathleen+M.+Nadeau%2C+p.xiv%2C+57+Quirino&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DC7YyfxKKPzwC%26dq%3Dhistory%2Bus%2Bphilippine%2Btrade%26source%3Dgbs_navlinks_s%3Dall&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AFerdinand+Marcos">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
          <span class="citation-comment" style="display:none; color:#33aa33; margin-left:0.3em">

         <span class="reference-text">

         <span class="reference-text">

           <a href="#cite_ref-344">
            ^

         <span class="reference-text">

            </i>

           . Asia-Pacific Press. pp. 99–110.

         (Report). International Crisis Group. 14 February 2011.
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=report&amp;rft.btitle=THE+COMMUNIST+INSURGENCY+IN+THE+PHILIPPINES%3ATACTICS+AND+TALKS%3B+Asia+Report+N%C2%B0202&amp;rft.pub=International+Crisis+Group&amp;rft.date=2011-02-14&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.refworld.org%2Fpdfid%2F4d5a310e2.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AFerdinand+Marcos">
         <span style="display:none;">
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <cite class="citation audio-visual" id="CITEREFSo_Why_Samar?">
         <a class="external text" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H6vw6rFaabA" rel="nofollow">
          <i>
           So Why Samar?
          </i>
         </a>
         .
         <i>
          Produced by the Philippine Commission on Human Rights with the help of Swiss Embassy Manila for its Oral History Project on the subject of human rights violations during martial law
         </i>
         .
         <a href="/wiki/Samar" title="Samar">
          Samar
         </a>
         : YouTube. October 3, 2015.
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=So+Why+Samar%3F&amp;rft.place=Samar&amp;rft.pub=YouTube&amp;rft.date=2015-10-03&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DH6vw6rFaabA&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AFerdinand+Marcos">
         <span style="display:none;">
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">
        Further reading
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>

      <ul>
       <li>
        <cite class="citation book">
         Aquino, Belinda, ed. (1982).
         <i>
          Cronies and Enemies: The Current Philippine Scene
         </i>
         . Philippine Studies Program, Center for Asian and Pacific Studies, University of Hawaii.
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Cronies+and+Enemies%3A+The+Current+Philippine+Scene&amp;rft.pub=Philippine+Studies+Program%2C+Center+for+Asian+and+Pacific+Studies%2C+University+of+Hawaii&amp;rft.date=1982&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AFerdinand+Marcos">

         Waltzing with a Dictator: The Marcoses and the Making of American Policy
        </i>
        . Times Books, New York
        <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
         ISBN
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8129-1326-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8129-1326-2">
         978-0-8129-1326-2

       <li>
        <cite class="citation book">
         Celoza, Albert F. (1997).
         <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Sp3U1oCNKlgC" rel="nofollow">
          <i>
           Ferdinand Marcos and the Philippines: the political economy of authoritarianism
          </i>
         </a>
         . Greenwood Publishing.
         <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
          ISBN
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-275-94137-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-275-94137-6">
          978-0-275-94137-6
         </a>
         .
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Ferdinand+Marcos+and+the+Philippines%3A+the+political+economy+of+authoritarianism&amp;rft.pub=Greenwood+Publishing&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-275-94137-6&amp;rft.au=Celoza%2C+Albert+F.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DSp3U1oCNKlgC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AFerdinand+Marcos">
         <span style="display:none;">
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <cite class="citation book">
         Robles, Raissa (2016).
         <a class="external text" href="https://www.facebook.com/MarcosMartialLawNeverAgain/" rel="nofollow">
          <i>
           Marcos Martial Law: Never Again
          </i>
         </a>
         .
         <a href="/wiki/Quezon_City" title="Quezon City">

         </a>

         <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">

         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-621-95443-1-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-621-95443-1-3">
          978-621-95443-1-3
         </a>
         .
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Marcos+Martial+Law%3A+Never+Again&amp;rft.place=Quezon+City&amp;rft.pub=Filipinos+for+a+Better+Philippines%2C+Inc.&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-621-95443-1-3&amp;rft.aulast=Robles&amp;rft.aufirst=Raissa&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FMarcosMartialLawNeverAgain%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AFerdinand+Marcos">
         <span style="display:none;">
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>

             </td>

               </a>
               from
               <a href="/wiki/Ilocos_Norte" title="Ilocos Norte">

               </a>

               </a>
              </b>
              <br/>
              1949–1959
             </td>

        <tr>
         <th class="navbox-title" colspan="3" scope="col">
          <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
           <ul>

                <ul>

               </div>
              </td>
             </tr>
